You don't get to do more than walk and interact with a few objects but this is an idea stripped to its very core. Why so many games still haven't learned a thing about bending the rules of nature to serve the player is interesting and after playing this you may understand why they haven't but why they should. 

Play it once, then turn on commentary and play it again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082331364', 'num_games_owned': 1524, 'num_reviews': 70, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1545019046}
review:
I've never written a game review on steam before but for something as awful as this, I really have to. I know this was mostly made by one person, but charging 5 goddamn dollars for this is an awful thing to do. 

First off, this game probably has the worst pc porting I've ever seen for any game in my entire life. (Pretty sure this game's only on pc too)
I have .4 hours on this game, and .3 of them were trying to get this game to goddamn be remotely functional. The options menu has very basic graphics settings, which isn't gamebreaking in of itself, but I'll save the performance for later. Every single time you dare sneeze at one of those options, pausing the game after setting them up just crashes the game, no matter what, which /I guess/ you don't need to pause because of the game's length, but that's a very backanded compliment. Also worth noting that the brightness setting just ups the brightness on your computer entirely, which is hilariously awful. Speaking of the game's performance, I tried on three seperate computers to get this game to run at a framerate above 10, and only with a 1,100 dollar setup was I able to get this game barely over 60fps. Not helping that fact is the game freezes all the time for a second+ each time. Another thing worth pointing out is that the game looks ugly as hell, shadows for objects appear twenty light years away from the object casting the shadow, there's plenty of characters floating above the ground, teleporting characters, among many other things. The game also never saves your settings too which is incredible considering every time you open it completely messes up your computer.
TL;DR game runs abysmally, looks abysmal, getting it to run is abysmal process. Framerate is terrible, even on a pc where I can play VR games ultra smooth and play games as impressive looking as AHiT at 144fps

Second, this game takes 5 minutes to beat, seriously. I wouldn't call it short but sweet either. What PC Gamer in the trailer is saying is a complete lie in every sense of the word. ok so like, in the game, you go into a bar, go into an armory, run around in an airport, then suddenly your friends are bloody, you take one god knows where (rip the other one) and then youre instantly dropped at a nausiating angle in a bedroom to go to a party, you go to the party, sit there for a couple seconds, get drunk, go back home, walk towards the friend you left behind and then suddenly youre dropped back to another place where I actually got softlocked due to the strange movement there, fun, and then youre back to taking your friend through the airport, in which you see the police and then you teleport onto a motorcycle with another nausiating angle, where you drive away. the end, oh but not until you get tought Bernoulli's principle of wind, which actually fucking happens in this game, and then youre back on the motorcycle, and die but also not die at the same time.
TL;DR game stole five bucks for a story less comprehensible and less enjoyable than watching unsubbed sword art online

Third, the game's super buggy and a huge lie. I already mentioned the softlock, pc settings, and the freezes, but some objects dont seem to work correctly at all, and the game's cutscenes have built-in model clipping for still, teleported in objects. Another thing is how the text "forger" appears in one of the game's screenshots, you don't forge anything, all you can do in this game is pick up objects with nothing gained from picking them up, eat oranges, and do whatever action the game requires you to press e once for, no forging of anything happens. The game says in the Steam store description as having lovelorn criminals, but it's never even shown what we're criminals for really, and the love only goes as far as awkward stares while the game has fun with bloom effects (maybe it's in the prequel but screw off I ain't playing that after this) I feel nothing after playing it other than regret. I also noticed some stock sound effects which is always SUPER immersive.
TL;DR Game lies about it's story and interactions and its even harder to make sense of it when having to deal with bugs

Trust me, you don't want to play this game, it's not even worth it free. 

Considering the fact that this game screws with your computer brightness and screws up your computer resolution, there's no debate whether this game is art or not the debate's over if it's a virus or not LMAO

author: {'steamid': '76561198064418587', 'num_games_owned': 428, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 79, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 79, 'last_played': 1530247266}
review:
30 flights of loving is a game that feels extremely fresh and unlike anything I've played. It's full to the brim with interesting and fun Ideas and also excellently paced.

It is also 15 minutes long and has almost no gameplay besides walking around.

There's a developers commentary mode that will bump up your overall time with the game to around an hour and also help shine some light on how much care went into the design of the game, because when you're actually playing it it all flies by in a flurry. Thirty flights of loving is the only walking simulator I've played yet that instead of being slow and deliberate moves along at a breakneck speed. That's what makes it special and that's also what makes it work in that incredibly short playtime. I recommend this game to those who have had good times with walking simulators before and who also don't mind paying 5 bucks for a game that's this short.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071544637', 'num_games_owned': 670, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1679257153}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving, seventh release of the "Citizen Abel" series, launched on August 20 of 2012 by Brendon Chung's indie studio Blendo Games, is a walking simulator or game-film that tells a story in 30 minutes or less.

In the time that will take to experience this narrative you aren’t going to find a deep plot, no sub-text, no message behind, the gameplay is above all lineal and basic, the graphics are quite obnoxious —the aesthetic corresponds amidst the objects, people, and so forth, but them are not elaborately real and gleamingly simplistic—, there is a lack of voice-acting which is replaced by a quirky and bizarre mumble, and foremost a large quantity of disorganized and chaotic sequences with only a small amount of sense.

So, how could it be so relevant to the foundation of vidya as a serious platform in which art, like an edifice of audiovisual interaction, will arise to entomb the capitalistic desire of entertainment as a tool for profitable alienation?

In cinema, just like it could happen in video games, there are some tools of which you can take advantage to create a more poetic, fast, vivid, sad, etcetera, ambient to the spectator. Geometry, composition, silence or music, and the length of a scene can create different emotions, interpretations and/or meanings of what the author is trying to tell by means of what is showed in the frames. Here Chung does not apply all of the previously said, but he does use of something really important: Montage. 
In Dziga Vertov's experimental 1929 Soviet silent documentary film "Man with a Movie Camera" the entire plot is told by montage, without dialogues and yet having a thread that connects the sequences providing a notable consistence. 

This mixture of Wong Kar-wai and Tarantino is a totally rich adventure in the way of how things should be told, grabbing a flat event recreated throughout history on countless occasions and giving it a fresh twist (although maybe if the story was longer it wouldn't have worked) from were a lot of devs could grab a tip or two.

7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197991262582', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 104, 'playtime_forever': 90, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 90, 'last_played': 1534901290}
review: Bizzare and blocky, this is one of several entries in the universe of the creative Blendo Games. It is a short first-person...well, I was going to say "shooter," but that's not right. It's more like an adventure game that tells a little espionage story. I liked very much this wonderful little experiment of narration and style but in all fairness it probably isn't for everyone. But it's not expensive and not long, which I actually like; we need more high-quality short games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198008096580', 'num_games_owned': 1731, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1534897568}
review:
I don't have a problem with artsy games, but I do appreciate a cohesive story far better than being told to connect the dots when the dots look different to everybody and.. Sorry, let me back up.

Years ago, I played Gravity Bone because people kept going on about how "great" it was and a positive example of how well indie developers understand narrative and how Blendo is looking at stories in ways people normally don't. What I got was possibly a sneak peek at the tail-end of someone's Creative Writing 101 story. "What did I just witness?" was probably a thought that crossed my mind back then. It certainly did after playing through Thirty Flights a few times.

I think the developer's own words kind of damn him. "You can never look at it with fresh eyes, you know the work inside and out." By that I mean that only the Chung really knows what the story is supposed to be about. Thirty Flights of Loving? More like Thirty People Have Thirty Interpretations. The dizzying jump-cuts, the references to 5 other games almost none of us have played (let along heard of), the deliberately vague "it's more interesting this way" storytelling. It's like, I KNOW there's a story there somewhere, but after almost an hour of playing the game (including commentary) and then another hour scouring the internet for some clues as to WHY so many people are infatuated with this game...

Pretend for a moment that you are sitting on a bench in a park. Perhaps you're sipping a coffee or watching people go about their business. Suddenly, a naked man runs screaming past followed by a flock of angry pigeons. A moment passes and they're gone, leaving behind only some stray feathers and a somewhat awkward "that was weird" feeling, and a nagging feeling that perhaps something important just happened.

That's how I feel after all this time. So many people seem to "get it" and yet just as many people do not, and depending on who you talk to you're either a pretentious snob liking something cause it's cool to do so or an uneducated fool who couldn't spot all the obvious tells of a See Spot Run book. Apologies, that sounded a bit harsh, but those are indeed reactions I have seen while trying to come to terms with this game. On the other hand, I certainly feel I had more to work with than Dear Esther. Thirty Flights tells the same story every time, it's your interpretations and understanding that change. This was decidedly not the case with the former.

This is a needlessly long and drawn out "review" because I don't want to just up and insult people who did or didn't get the game. I, personally, felt there was something inherently lazy about expecting your audience to piece everything together without giving them more to go on. However, the music is wonderful and the visuals are charming. I don't disparage Thirty Flights nor its creator, but I can't deny that "not getting it" does make me feel foolish. This is perhaps due to the fact that after replaying Gravity Bone and thinking about the connection between the games, I have still come up short.

And being told by the likes of PC Gamer and Rock Paper Shotgun that this is an "amazing" game and "better than actual spy movies" definitely doesn't help. I just can't escape the feeling that games like this are the virtual equivalent of Lost. Where everything is in the creator's head, they're not going to give you a straight answer, and either everyone is wrong or nobody is wrong. Which does not make for a very enjoyable story.

I can't even say "you'll like this if you liked Gravity Bone", because they're both quite different experiences. I CAN say that this is most definitely an art game, and perhaps that's all you need to know.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977992736', 'num_games_owned': 824, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1532980241}
review:

nuance. I loved the Quake 2 engine graphics. They had a style I appreciated. The other game in this Gravity Bones, I enjoyed much more.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101046856', 'num_games_owned': 1025, 'num_reviews': 60, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1514393881}
review:
Can a game be art?

So this is the game that influenced Virginia, at least in terms of how the story was told. I like the approach, it's basically giving you only the necessary information und cuts straight to the next scene. You could compare it to a memory or life flashing before your eyes before you die. You still have the important stuff stored in your brain but it's impossible to remember everything and this is what makes this game one of a kind. In terms of stroytelling, and this is all the game really wants to be, it's a revolution and definatelly a step forward for the walking simulator genre, as you can clearly see when playing Virginia, which takes it to the next level.

If you're interested in this kind of stuff and story and the way it's presented to the gamer, I would recommend trying out this game. However I do think 5 bucks are questionable, as this is litterally one memory and took me not even half an hour to get through. It's a piece of art though, so I leave it up to you to decide whether 5 bucks is too much for the time in game or not enough for the brilliant inovations presented here.

I definatelly enjoyed myself and hope there's more like this in the making. Recommended.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972880843', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1531058371}
review:
Le jeu propose une expérience qui se démarque un petit peu mais qui est très loin d'être un choc "wtf!" ou un exemple d'originalité. Ca reste plat, premier degré et "ok" tout le long. Les contrôles sont approximatifs et le gameplay et les niveaux sont basiques, donnant plus l'impression de jouer à un protoype.

Le côté prototype est d'autant plus présent à cause de la technique du jeu. Je ne parle pas de ses personanges carrés et du style graphique (qui font partie des points "plutôts positifs" du jeu)  mais réellement de la technique "basique" du jeu, à savoir: ne pas crasher.

Lorsqu'on ouvre le menu pause, qu'on sauvegarde ou qu'on charge une partie, 50% du temps le jeu crash. Chaque crash du jeu remet à zéro tous les paramètres (son/graphismes/contrôles), on est donc forcés de jouer en qwerty, 720p (avec des paramètres graphiques détectés au pif), le son à fond et en se forçant et ne jamais  appuyer sur la touche échap ou sauvegarde rapide pour ne pas perdre sa progression dans la niveau.

Enfin, les sauvegardes manuelles ne fonctionnant pas (même lorsque ça ne crash pas) le petit passage de plateforme de la 2e partie du jeu (rendu délicat, principalement à cause des contrôles du jeu) devient une véritable une puisque l'erreur est fatale et force à recommencer le niveau. Niveau qui n'est pas très long, mais qui n'est pas non plus intéressant la première fois et pénible à refaire.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063214686', 'num_games_owned': 817, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 8, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1530299961}

review: wtf even is this. This game is about 10 minutes long and managed to crash 5 times in those 10 minutes and I was only able to finish it once I left everything in default settings. Couldn't even change the resolution. I'm not a fan of games that are shorter than your average youtube video.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067420779', 'num_games_owned': 2084, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1530116562}
review:
So I think I got this for 3.99 and I can definitively say that it wasn't worthwhile to me. I played through both full games in my 30 minutes and got some enjoyment out of them but nowhere near enough to justify the price. For a buck this would've been fine to me. 

Aside from the price difficulties this is definitely a walking sim type game with low interactivity but it uses some very interesting film techniques and references to tell a nice little story. If you're interested in learning how to fit a lot of story into a short time without exposition dumps or some good editing techniques to make your world stand out more, this game is pretty great. Aside from that the story itself is only really ok, the gameplay is meager at best, and the art, aside from the music, is pretty poor. (I missed a pretty significant plot point because I couldn't see the difference between two characters and misunderstood a decent amount)

I'd personally advise watching a playthrough or waiting till it's cheaper as unless you really like spy movies and want a cute semi-parody or are an aspiring game dev wanting to see a test of film techniques and some references this game probably won't be worth it to you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030691885', 'num_games_owned': 2037, 'num_reviews': 651, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1529795870}

author: {'steamid': '76561198026317882', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1527447717}
review:
I tend to dislike experimental games, but TFOL works wonderfully well, as a short story narrated through ellipsises, flashbacks and flashforward. It evokes the feelings of heists movies, and is quick enough as to not become bothersome. A fun 10 min experience.

I even enjoyed "replaying" it with the dev commentaries, to get some interesting insights on the thought process behind it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198078887697', 'num_games_owned': 1797, 'num_reviews': 661, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1505441903}
review:
This game ended up in one of my trash bundles where steam cards were paying for the bundle itself.

This is a game you can watch, not play. 

Edit: In 2022, to be clear, I don't hate the idea or the concept, it just doesn't end up being a very interactive experience.

It does, however, raise the ethical question of whether watching the let's play is piracy or not. I own this game, but I got it in one of three bundles I bought on February 23, 2017 from Bundlestars, paying a total of $3 USD for 147 steam keys. At that point, does the game have any value? What about other games - is exposure worth the cost of no royalties on game footage? Would anyone watching a playthrough have bought the game anyway?

I don't know the answers to these questions, and Thirty Flights of Loving won't help you find them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067896869', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1525747372}

author: {'steamid': '76561198035644453', 'num_games_owned': 1089, 'num_reviews': 328, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1525728953}
review:
An interesting experiment in story telling in video games that utilizes "jump cuts" to speed along the game & sets up various "scenes" to tell the story w/ no spoken dialogue. I really think it succeeded in using these techniques, it would be interesting to see them used in a longer/bigger budget game.

As it stands Thirty Flights of Loving is an interesting experiment, but it's very short (I finished it in ~10 minutes) so I wouldn't recommend it to most people.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053953472', 'num_games_owned': 1944, 'num_reviews': 158, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1525636659}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving is an experience, it tells a story with a lot of jumpcuts, reminding me of Virginia. A playthrough takes about 15 minutes, the previous game (which is a free download from the developer's website) is also included. The game has no dialogue, with just a bit of optional exposition explaining who the two other main characters are.

I can't say I cared much for this one. You might still want to check it out due to what a unique experience it is.

Would be better if changing the settings didn't make the game crash and reset all settings. Had to play at default settings due to this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030006913', 'num_games_owned': 6506, 'num_reviews': 386, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1522527062}
review:
게임이라기 보단 인터렉티브 영화같은 느낌인데, 많은 이야기를 짧은 장면 전환으로 담아내서 말그대로 후다닥 서사를 전해 버린다.
마치 콘티만 읽은 느낌이라고 할까. 3줄 요약 뭐 그런 느낌이다.

다만 서사를 짧게 끊는 느낌만 강렬하지 뭔가 와닿는 그런게 없다. 예를들면 포탈도 한시간짜리 짧은 게임이지만 Cake is a lie! 와 애퍼쳐 뒷면을 보는 그런 강렬한 경험 말이다.
서사도 너무 뻔해서 임팩트가 없고.

게임이라기엔 너무 애매해서 비추 주려고 한다.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995320267', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1521707268}
review: It's not really a game.  It's a surreal, minimalist, semi-interactive short film.  It tells you to walk, and gives you just enough freedom to stumble, but not to run.  I can't really say I found it entertaining, intrguiging, or in any way fun.  If you want something that's Different-with-a-captial-D, this is it, but otherwise I'd recommend that you save your money and watch a Let's Play for the same experience. Or just skip it altogether.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082824785', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 84, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 84, 'last_played': 1367046000}
review: While the plot and characters are cliché, the unusual editing makes this into something quite special. This is a rifling gameplay experience, which manages to develop more intrigue and suspense in fifteen minutes than most games do in ten hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002237289', 'num_games_owned': 1138, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1519136520}
review:
After powering through 5 crashes, I finally perservered with playing this in a sub-720p resolution. Not great. Especially when I realised that the amount of time battling with the graphics settings and files in an attempt to play this was such a large percentage of my overall eventual playtime.

You could argue that, as this only attempts to be a short game with no dialogue, that it does its job well. I disagree, when you've played games like Jazzpunk, you can only compare TFoL to other games. This is awful. Short, no humour, nothing clever, no experience to tell others about, nothing to subvert the gameplay. 

This isn't a game, and not like in the way the COD kiddies like to proclaim walking simulators as 'not a game'. This is just sub-par and distinctly below average. Don't waste your time, play JAZZPUNK.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018907859', 'num_games_owned': 1447, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1614032840}
review:
I bought the game due to it's high Metacritic rating back when Steam did not have it's refund policy in place.

Unfortunately, Thirty Flights of Loving is the worst $5 I have ever spent on a video game in my entire life. There is no substance, no depth, no replayability, no anything. Each "playthrough" takes around 5 minutes, and if you have played it once you have played everything it has to offer.

Don't waste your money like I did.

review:

Played it 3x, once with commentary. Even non-FPS adventure game fans will likely enjoy this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071761735', 'num_games_owned': 937, 'num_reviews': 43, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 56, 'last_played': 1642327142}
review: An amazing game that tells its entire story through filmic language. While it feels short, the game doesn't over stay its welcome and is so enjoyable and interesting that the fact you can beat the game in a half hour doesn't really matter. While I recomend this game, if the art style and concept intrest you, Blendo Games Quadrilateral Cowboy may intrest you more as that game has a bit more "gameplay" than this game. Despite the short length though I highly recommend this game if you are at all interested in what games can be beyond just simple genre tropes, and how games can tell stories in different ways.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050967938', 'num_games_owned': 2987, 'num_reviews': 176, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1520632393}
review:
L'ho completato in 10 minuti. Detto questo, posso solo aggiungere che sono stati 10 minuti perfetti.

Nessun dialogo, tutto è narrato visualmente con un'efficacia poderosa, a partire dalle rapidissime descrizioni dei nostri compagni d'avventura con pochi secondi di immagini. Ah, la grafica sfrutta l'engine di Quake II (!!!) ed è composta di poligoni molto grezzi ma arrangiati con gusto e sono subito adorabili le persone "cubiche".

Thirty Flights of Loving parla di amore ai tempi degli agenti segreti, di come questo sentimento possa essere travolgente e doloroso anche per loro, che però sono costretti a viverlo in maniera ancora più sfuggente e precaria.

Non ci sono tempi morti, neanche i corridoi vengono fatti attraversare per intero mentre la regia ci detta tagli che ci restituiscono senza sosta a qualche attività. Quando i momenti si dilatano è solo per farci sentire qualcosa, maledettamente bene.

Super consigliato. Non mi sorprendono i tanti pareri negativi, è un gioco molto molto particolare.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041969034', 'num_games_owned': 643, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1506776147}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968548984', 'num_games_owned': 2375, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1357027200}
review: I get what the game is going for, a really effecient narrative but its still 5 bucks for twelve minutes of gameplay.

author: {'steamid': '76561198045716689', 'num_games_owned': 1046, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1516087795}
review:
There is a great concept in here, and the soundtrack is pretty good. The art style is good for what it is, but for $5 I was expecting something more. The playtime on my account says 0.3 hours, but that is actually quite inflated; it's actually mostly from restarting the game over and over again as I adjusted the video settings; it would crash out pretty frequently. I didn't have any issues once the game actually started up, but just getting to that point took an average of 3 tries. I was going to check out [i]Gravity Bone[/i] as well, but the game crashed out [b]again[/b]. The game crashes out of the [i]menu screen[/i] frequently, so that's gonna be a hard pass for me.

It's a shame, because there are some really neat ideas in here. At the time of writing, the game has been out for 5 ½ years, so I don’t think we’ll be getting a patch any time soon…

author: {'steamid': '76561198046480201', 'num_games_owned': 1340, 'num_reviews': 82, 'playtime_forever': 50, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 50, 'last_played': 1515879141}
review:
El juego no puede ser más corto... pero me ha dejado una sensación increible. Narrativa absolutamente magnífica para mi gusto. Una grandísima experiencia en un botecito muy pequeño. También ha ayudado a mi experiencia que no tenía ni la más remota idea de qué me iba a encontrar ni de cómo se jugaba al juego o qué estilo sería.

Claramente no es un producto para todos los públicos, pero para mí ha sido una genialidad. Esto es como comprar un poema, si lo entiendes, te puede tocar la fibra, si no, son simplemente letras juntas...

Ahora bien, esto que digo es relativo a Thirty Flights of Loving, porque la parte de gravity bone que es como un extra, para mí no vale mucho... no es igual...

author: {'steamid': '76561198182751118', 'num_games_owned': 969, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1515472695}
review: Si Godard hiciese un cortometraje en forma de videojuego saldría algo como esto. Altamente experimental, dura en torno a 10-15 minutos, no más, y prácticamente no existen mecánicas. Es un pasillo, te muestran la historia, y se termina. A mí me ha gustado, pero hay que tomárselo como lo que es: vanguardismo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986853226', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 300, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1514868086}
review:
This package includes Gravity Bone and 30 Flights of Lovin. Both are extremely short, linear, first person narrative experiences that I didn't find particularly interesting. 

The full package had some wonky sound balance, doesn't display correctly at full screen on my duel-monitor setup, and doesn't seem to track my mouse very well. On pause menus and ingame the games would react as if my mouse was moving even when it was still. This resulted in the first person camera drifting.

Gameplay for both games amounted to walking, poor first-person platforming, an uninteresting activities like "take this picture" or "use x on y." Interspaced throughout were sudden jumps, obviously intended to act like jump-cuts in film, that were often fairly disorienting.

The plots, a large focus of both games, is explained chiefly through action instead of text. However, even under such limitation, there is a strange lack of detail. The player is bounced through moments that vary from ridiculous to serious in seconds. The result feels extremely half-baked.

After playing and enjoying Jazzpunk I thought these games would be right up my alley. However, the technical issues, poor gameplay, and plot have left me wondering why these titles are so highly regarded.

author: {'steamid': '76561198144311714', 'num_games_owned': 257, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 62, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 62, 'last_played': 1514304712}
review:
Thirty flights of loving est un jeu... euh... tellement original qu'il m'est difficile de le décrire. En fait en achetant ce jeu, on obtient non pas un mais deux jeux puisque celui ci comprend en plus de "Thirty flights of loving", le jeu "Gravity Bone" téléchargeable gratuitement sur le site des développeurs. Perso j'ai découverts "Thirty flights" grâce à Gravity Bone que j'avais téléchargé depuis Romstation gratuitement évidemment. Du coup je vais en premier évoquer Gravity Bone et je vous parlerais ensuite de Thirty Flights.

Gravity Bone est un jeu gratuit où l'on contrôle une sorte d'agent secret à travers 2 niveaux. Le premier a une durée de 2 à 5 minutes. Il s'agit tout simplement d'un petit niveau où on se retrouve à se déguiser en serveur pour discrètement empoisonner un homme. Ce niveau sert surtout de tutoriel. On enchaine ensuite avec le second niveau qui se fait en 10 à 20 minutes maximum. Dans celui ci, on a pour objectif de photographier 5 oiseaux (je ne sais pas vraiment pourquoi et je soupçonne les développeurs de ne pas le savoir non plus). On se retrouve donc dans une sorte d'hotel avec en inventaire un appareil photo et également du materiel permettant de détruire des cadenas. Sans spoil, la fin de ce premier jeu est vraiment excellente. Alors qu'on ne s'y attend pas du tout, un rebondissement a lieu, et on se retrouve alors à faire une course poursuite réellement bien réalisé et vraiment drôle.

Visuellement le jeu n'est pas spécialement beau mais la direction artistique reste très original et je l'apprécie réellement. En ce qui concerne l'audio, il n'y a pas grand chose à dire. On retiendra quand même quelques musiques, celle du premier niveau et celles de la course poursuite. Pour le gameplay, c'est assez pauvre, on peutvmzrcher sauter et utiliser notre materiel... rien d'incroyable. Sinon on ne peut pas changer les commandes, c'est regrettable mais acceptable pour un jeu gratuit. On a donc avec ce jeu une expérience gratuite très appréciable que je vous conseille réellement. Le studio a alors pris le pari de faire un jeu du même style mais cette fois ci payant. Ce risque a t'il payé?

Thirty flights of loving commence sans page d'accueil, comme son prédécesseur. Ce jeu est assez difficile à diviser en plusieurs niveaux, mais on peut le diviser en 3 parties. L'intro, le jeu, et la conclusion qui est en fait le générique. Dans l'intro, on se retrouve dans un bar issue d'une cachette secrète. On rencontre donc nos deux coéquipiers dont j'ai totalement oublié les noms, qui sont un homme et une femme. Après avoir fait connaissance (de façon humoristique) avec eux et leurs caractéristiques, on rentre dans un avion et le jeu commence réellement. 
Et là c'est assez difficile à expliquer mais on alterne entre deux actions totalement différentes. La première se situe dans un aéroport avec nos deux alliés blessés. Il faut donc amener notre coéquipier en fauteuil roulant faire un tour de l'aéroport. Toute cet action est coupé par des scènes qui j'imagine se sont passés avant cette mésaventure où nos 3 héros sont les invités un mariage, et après plusieurs bouteilles d'alcool, on comprend que notre personnage et notre coéquipiere sont amoureux. Et... c'est tout.

En gros ce second jeu dure 20 à 30 minutes. C'est à dire autant pour ne pas dire moins de temps que pour le précédent jeu qui je le rappelle était gratuit. Alors autant pour un jeu gratuit c'est tout à fait excusable autant là c'est franchement une honte. Après on peut se dire que le jeu est court mais il doit être intense et d'une grande qualité. Non! Non je considère même ce jeu inferieur qualitativement vis a vis du premier. Il y a une régression. Tout d'abord il n'y a plus de materiel comme celui que nous possédions dans le premier. Il n'y a même pas de passages de plateforme comme dans le premier. Pas de scène mémorable comme la fin du premier. Et d'ailleurs en parlant de fin, celle ci est réellement mauvaise. Elle arrive comme un cheveux sur la soupe de façon très abrupte et surprenante... En ce qui concerne le scénario, autant j'avais un peu compris le premier (même si certaines choses m'ont échappé) autant là c'est très peu compréhensible. Avec tout ces changements de lieux et de temporalités, on y comprend presque rien. Et tant que j'y suis... OU ES LE LIEN AVEC GRAVITY BONE?? Serieusment est ce que l'action se passe avant ou après. J'aurais tendance à dire après mais ce n'est qu'une idée personnelle.

Sinon visuellement c'est toujours aussi réussi. Au niveau de l'audio c'est assez peu mémorable. Mais le vrai problème c'est que le jeu crash beaucoup! Il m'a été impossible d'y jouer en plein écran sans soucis. Sinon ce que je retiendrais outre l'intro assez réussi, c'est une scène dans l'aéropeort ou notre coéquipier tire sur des caméras de police qui tombét du ciel, une scène assez amusante et original. Sinon, je peux pas dire que j'ai passé un mauvais moment sur ce jeu. Certe je l'ai bien démonté jusque là, mais c'est parce que c'est tellement dommage. Ce jeu a été une vraie déception. En achetant ce jeu, je suis en droit d'espérer une version améliorée et plus longue de Gravity Bone. Or là non! Le jeu n'est même pas plus long et qualitativement il est inferieur à Gravity Bone!

Ce jeu est une vraie déception. Je n'ais pas passé un mauvais moment devant ce jeu, mais c'est tellement dommage, on dirait que les développeurs se sont contentés du minimum. En réunissant les deux jeux, il est très facilement finissable en 45 minutes. On peut au moins se dire qu'avec une campagne solo si courte, la rejouabilité peut être plus simple. Malheureusement ce jeu qui possède quelques qualités (je pense au visuel mais aussi à quelques passages des deux jeux ) est gâchée par de très nombreux défauts comme la durée du jeu, le gameplay très pauvre, le scénario ou encore l'îstabilité de celui ci. 
Je le déconseille fortement, surtout à 5€, c'est de l'arnaque. À 2,50€ cela est plus raisonnable mais c'est toujours trop pour ce qu'il a à proposer. Par contre je vous conseille Gravity Bone (qui représente 50% de mon achat) trouvable gratuitement sur le site des développeurs.

Note: 7,5/20

author: {'steamid': '76561197960382659', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1511745532}
review:
There is a term thrown around in gaming that refers to moments, or segments, as "cinematic."Those people usually are referring to large and epic set pieces that involve a lot of explosions and lots of action, something that'd you'd see in a typical Hollywood summer blockbuster. 

Thirty Flights of Loving, much like Chung's first game, "Gravity Bone," utilizies cinema's most precious and powerful gift, editing. Chung cuts scenes together that not only builds tension, but suspense and excitement in a truly invovative and creative way. 

It is a short experience, but well worth your time if you enjoy caper stories and a truly "cinematic" experience.

It's a game that lends credence to the argument that video games can be considered art.

author: {'steamid': '76561198171029234', 'num_games_owned': 338, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1509859694}

author: {'steamid': '76561198024575644', 'num_games_owned': 366, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 141, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 141, 'last_played': 1511432947}
review:
This game is clearly not for everyone. 
I loved this game, immediately, from the first second to the last. 
It was an amazing and totally new gaming experience to me and i want mooooaaaaaar! :p
This game left me in a strange state of mind the first time i played it. WTF did i just play? ^^
I got it for as little as 1.5 euros i think. It was worth it dammit. 
I recommend this game to everyone though. 
The game can be very cheap, so if you don't like it, you won't be too disappointed spending the money. Besides, you could also let your friends try it too and see their reactions ^^ (the game is so short btw, it's easy to finish it VERY quickly).
And if, like me, it happens to be a major good surprise, then...you're winner! ^^
I'll play it again in a few minutes btw. 
AS SHOULD YOU! :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198044621170', 'num_games_owned': 766, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1510689524}
review:
I didn't get it. Gravity Bone is better as it gives you something to do. Look, if your going to have a story in the form of a game you need to have some sort of flow, not jerking from one scene to the next randomly. The characters motivations aren't clear throughout, after reading a story on here, I get it, but you need to have 1 of better animation/dialogue/simpler storyline to make it understood and you can't do that as it would ruin the style.

So simply put it's a flawed story where the story is unintelligableand the gaming aspects aren't really there. The developers commentary is a nice touch and it gives some insights into his process, I wish other games did something similar, however during this the developer himself points out things he'd change if he made this game again, and that infuriates me, because if you aren't happy with what you have made why are you putting it as a paid game on steam! (£4 isn't much, but still...) The "game" is more a prototype/unfinished/hastily finished work and as such is pretty shoddy.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996945566', 'num_games_owned': 300, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1510517129}
review:
A story with action, a car chase, guns, intrigue, crime, love and betrayal told without text or dialogue, delivered in under 20 minutes.

If Lord of the Rings is 10 pints of beer
30 Flights of Loving is a shot of 100% ethanol

review:
This isn't for everyone but I really enjoyed it. It's ridiculous, has interesting pacing, uses a bunch of fun tropes. The style gives you snapshots of information that lead you to imagining the rest of the story, which I like. But like everyone is saying, it is very short.

review:

✔ A atmosfera do jogo é bem imersiva, apesar de confusa.

✖ Assim que o jogo começa, ele termina...

É interessante a interação dada com o jogo em breves momentos e a tentativa de imaginar a história entre essas lacunas.
Mas o tempo de jogo não é suficiente pra que esse contexto faça muito sentido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007712873', 'num_games_owned': 1401, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 89, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 89, 'last_played': 1474872184}

author: {'steamid': '76561198080449011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1521393199}
review:
El juego es demasiado corto, así que me centraré en las etapas alrededor de él:
1. Lo habrás escuchado de alguien como DayoScript y no le tomaste demasiada importancia.
2. Tienes dinero de sobra y sientes que te puedes dar un pequeño lujo "por amor al arte de los videojuegos".
3. Lo empiezas y tienes un escepticismo inicial.
4. Inevitablemente entras en las mecánicas del juego, sintiendo la historia cada vez más vivida. 
5. Llegas al final y solo repites cuán cierto es todo lo que dijeron de él... o te arrepientes porque esperabas un <<<auténtico FPS>>>.
6. En el caso de la primera, tienes la imperiosa necesidad de mostrarlo y dar a conocer cómo esta industria es más que los clichés y grandes producciones y que es un placer vivir en esta época. 

Aquí vienes por una historia y la forma de contarla, no por la jugabilidad o las mecánicas. A conectar con personajes en pocos minutos y a sentir las emociones del protagonista anónimo en cada una de las partes. Vas a querer más, pero este bocado se quedará bien marcado en tu memoria por mucho tiempo. 
Tómalo como un chocolate amargo, llega a parecer relativamente caro por lo que ofrece y que no te va a dar el mismo gusto como todos los demás dulces o comidas más substanciosas. Pero es perfectamente disfrutable. Y en serio, compártelo.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072816018', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1558920878}
review:
Yes, this is a short game. Yes, it is absolutely worth your time. The narrative structure of this experience is wholly unlike anything I've seen before, and it absolutely enthralled me. Games like this are what push the medium developmentally forward. I am willing to call [i] Thirty Flights of Loving [/i] a masterpiece, and I truly hope it inspires players and developers alike.
I highly recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001402426', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1501704152}
review:
You know, I'm fine with the whole "short story as a game" thing. There isn't much actual gameplay here and that's really OK. I'm ok with there being no dialogue, just a wah-wah sound like when the adults talk in Charlie Brown. It's like a silent movie. I'm fine with the comically bad art style, where everything is boxes and rectangles and polygons. Graphics don't make a story. I'm even fine with an incredibly ambiguous story that leaves you to piece together flashbacks and fragments.

What I'm not OK with is the complete lack of [i]content[/i] here. You can see that I played this game for 30 minutes. That's all there is to it. 30 minutes covers two "stories," one in which you relive the last days of a heist team, and one in which you are a secret agent of some kind, doing missions for a "contract agency." I played this game for 30 minutes and saw everything there was to see. I didn't speed-run the thing; I wanted to drink in the little slices of life the developers were giving me, but there was barely a thimbleful to drink. The second story especially could have done with more missions. The first one was short, but involves you stealing a waiter's uniform at a party and literally "bugging" a VIP. The second mission has you breaking into rooms with freon and a hammer and taking pictures of birds before they explode. But, instead of allowing you to spend a little more time in their world, the developers simply have you get shot at the end of the second mission and tell you it's over.

I found the whole thing intensely unsatisfying. If you're going to tell tiny stories with games, then great, DO THAT. Tell stories. Make a whole anthology. Build a world and let me play in snippets of it. Don't charge me 5 bucks for two incredibly short experiences that blow up their premises within ten minutes of starting them.

author: {'steamid': '76561197997711695', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1487897261}

author: {'steamid': '76561198260288411', 'num_games_owned': 394, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487166852}
review:
Simplemente no lo recomiendo. Lo he conseguido gratis en un sorteo en Reddit pero aun así no lo recomiendo para nada ¿Por Que? 
 Bien para empezar el juego es demasiado pero demasiado corto y no es que sea un problema menor. No no no. El juego en si solo dura entre unos 10 a 30 minutos, y no es que sean unos 30 minutos de pura acción. No, no hay interacción con el personaje y el entorno. La única interacción que hay es a a los primeros minutos del juego en donde recoges armas, balas y cerveza, las cuales al final no sirven para nada, los únicos enemigos que matas ni siquiera los matas tu, los mata tu compañero. Simplemente lo único que haces en todo el juego es mover a tu personaje y abrir puertas.

 No me puedo creer que el juego salga 5 dolares considerando lo corto que es, he visto juegos a 5 dolares mucho mas largos y con mas rejugabilidad. Si saldría como entre menos de un dolar e incluso gratis podría entender lo corto que es. 

 No hay rejugabilidad. El juego en si tiene 0 de rejugabilidad. No hay ni secretos, ni logros para justificar esos 10-30 minutos.
 
 Y si te preguntaras ¿El juego tiene algo de bueno?. Bien su música es disfrutable, los gráficos son un Meh, aunque bien es un juego indie, así que se podría llegar a justificar(aun así el resto del juego sigue siendo injustificable)

Resumen: No lo compren, es muy corto, casi no hay interacción, ni rejugabilidad
4/10

review:
A complete waste of time. The story is pretentious and poorly told, and the game is low quality in all aspects. At best, it might pass for a proof of concept - it is certainly not a game worthy of your time.
[Rating: 0/10]

author: {'steamid': '76561198068102627', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 144, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1500504908}
review: Lame walking simulator.

author: {'steamid': '76561198012153188', 'num_games_owned': 847, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 20, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1499619786}
review:
Its more like an abstract art experience than a video game, but the concept of telling a story purely through environment and scenarios, without any real form of dialog, is one I found very interesting. I enjoyed my play-through a lot, and despite it being rather short (I finished it in about 25 minutes, but I explored every environment thoroughly as I played) I didn't feel like I was short-changed.

The story is the whole point of this game, and while not entirely groundbreaking in itself, it is delivered in a way not regularly seen in video games lately; It leaves working out whats going on up to you. If you want to, you can ignore any of the details and sprint for the next area, or you can slow down, look around, and take in all the subtleties.

It may not be a game for most, but I think its a healthy attempt at changing the rules conventional video games treat as gospel, and it should be praised for its effort.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027102438', 'num_games_owned': 1328, 'num_reviews': 156, 'playtime_forever': 63, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 63, 'last_played': 1500076649}
review:
OK so I was trying to take this game seriously until I realized the game doesn't take me seriously.

Tried to complete it until I reached a practically impossible jump (on Gravity Bone) which somehow worked well on youtube video of the game.

Oh Well no big deal, I did get the sense there was some intention of telling a story here, I did bother to read all the devs. commentary (really!) but I ended up very confused about what was going on here.

Not sure it's worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198020035960', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1499996090}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving? more like Thirty Seconds of Gameplay amirite ha ha ha yeah but no. This game is weird and I love it. 

There are seriously few games that can hit the note this one does, with its blend of nonsense non-linearity, unabashed smash-cuts and richly coloured surroundings. Lights and sounds blend and overlap in strange ways. strange, plastic people surge around you. those tiny noises that repeat in your mind are brought to life in an continual flow of conciousness. Overwhelmingly, it gives off the feeling of being in a dream or a half forgotten memory; The places you are have a palpable character & feeling to them, be it the oppresive paranoid rush of an airport or the comfortable warmth in a lantern-lit city roof, but the details of where you are or how you got there are often lost. If I had to compare it to anything, I'd say it's a lot like Yume Nikki, or Cat Soup, or a few songs off of Sawako's Madoromi, in how small and personal it can be, plus the drowsy, near-soporiphic (but in a good way) tone it has. I don't think I've ever played a game that so perfectly captures the feeling of waking up at 5pm in the summer, or even tries to.

This game probably isn't for everyone. It's really damn short, and you can easily blaze through it in 5 minutes or less. However, the length of it is something that doesn't exactly bother me. Actual dreams often get cut off and mixed around and forgotten at both ends, and the game leaves me with a feeling that this is neither the beginning nor the end of what happened here, so it adds to that dreamlike quality for me. Just make sure you know that you're in for a short ride if you buy it. For me, it's like revisitng somewhere in your mind. A recurring dream where you can just drift away and be lost in the whirling colour for a little while. I recommend trying it at 3am, when you're a little sleepy. It can draw you in, that way.

author: {'steamid': '76561198086670406', 'num_games_owned': 244, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1499876274}
review:
For the full price, I can't recommend this game. I finished it in 10 minutes. The other 10 minutes of Gameplay that I have were launcher crashes when adjusting the resolution to 1080p. 

The game itself is very pretentious. It might be that I didn't understand the idea, but it felt like looking at a piece of abstract art. It didn't provoke any feelings or make me feel sympathy for anything or anyone. 

Even though Quadrilateral Cowboy seems like a game I'd enjoy and Thirty Flights Of Loving is from the same team, I didn't enjoy this game at all. Play through it if you get it on a bundle, like me. I'd say this game is worth $0.50 or $1 at most, and that's being VERY gentle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972520799', 'num_games_owned': 999, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1499386119}
review: Walking simulator pretensioso, não oferece gameplay, história ou desafio. Somente a trilha sonora como ponto positivo.

author: {'steamid': '76561197986364689', 'num_games_owned': 262, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1497447122}

author: {'steamid': '76561198314172349', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1502057135}

author: {'steamid': '76561198034423768', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 154, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1499154533}
review: Thirty Flights of Loving just didn't have enough going on for me to grasp on to.  I think what I would like this game to be was actually much better realized by Jazzpunk -- but maybe that means this was the influence required to make that happen.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982962818', 'num_games_owned': 605, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1499028101}

author: {'steamid': '76561198069748932', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1500144548}
review:
Cortísimo incluso con el otro juego que viene incluído, pero funciona como experimento. Es probable que en un futuro alguien retome lo que este juego experimentó en cuanto a la narrativa y el corte para llevarlo más allá.
El precio es excesivo, pero si sabes buscar, puedes hallarlo jodidamente barato incluso fuera de las rebajas.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133727537', 'num_games_owned': 228, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 133, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 77, 'last_played': 1641762785}
review:
Una experiencia a vivir altamente recomendada. El precio es un poco alto para la cantidad de tiempo que ofrece, por eso cogerlo en rebajas considerables. Fuera de eso, jugarlo una vez en "vanilla" es la experiencia, pero luego jugarlo con los comentarios del creador dando sus ideas, sus frustraciones, sus inspiraciones y el amor que le tiene al juego es increíble. Te muestra procesos del diseño de creación de videojuegos desde un punto de vista artístico y en menor cantidad técnico. Además, viene con el anterior juego "Gravity Bone" incluido el cual es igual de corto pero vale la pena, una lástima que este no tenga los comentarios del creador porque me hubiese gustado saber por qué colocó las escenas de la forma que hizo. 

9/10 - Experimental, creativo, único y breve.

author: {'steamid': '76561198037210732', 'num_games_owned': 568, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 98, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 98, 'last_played': 1498725502}

review: Pretentious as hell """""game""""" that IS UNDER 20 MINUTES LONG. I've seen asmr videos with more depth and entertainment than this crap, and they're longer as well. Buy and refund just to send a middle finger to the devs for making such a steaming pile of garbage

author: {'steamid': '76561198010492777', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1498533555}
review:
Bad reviews do not come when your game is bad, but when you fail to deliver on your promises.

30 Flights of Loving is a HIGHLY conceptual/abstract walking simulator that aims to deliver a Coen Brothers movie and get it all expressed with no dialog or text boxes. Does it get there? Ehhhh, not really.

We are more forgiving these days of pixel art/bad graphics in service of a truly unique story - the problem is 30 Flights of Loving doesn't have one. There are no twists and turns, an average episode of Leverage would be a better use of your 30 minutes. Even at $3, I didn't feel like I got my money's worth.

It's just not interesting, compelling or nice to look at. It feels like a 48 hour game-jam title that someone released for some reason.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047420890', 'num_games_owned': 155, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1378352911}
review: weird af

author: {'steamid': '76561198068357954', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 36, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 36, 'last_played': 1498322055}
review:
It's not a game. Now, normally this wouldn't bother me at all. The Beginner's Guide is one of my favorite "games", and it's more of an expirience. Now, there are several things that made me return this.

1. The Length. I beat it in 15 minutes, then again in 10. This is crazily short, and it dosen't have alot of replay value. This then goes to my next point.

2. The Price. For every $5 a game costs, it should have at least 2 hours of gameplay. For example, a game that's $10 should  at least have 4 hours of gameplay. This game is $5 and has about 15 minutes of gameplay. That's terrible. This game should be a dollar, if anything.

3. The Actual Gameplay. There is none, except you just walking around. Now don't get me wrong, I'm a huge fan of walking simulators, like as I said before, The Beginner's Guide is one of my favorite games. In that game you just walk around, but there's commentary and narration that drives you through. It has a story that drives you in. In this game the story is really bad. If the stories bad, then the gameplay should be the thing to drive you through, but all you do is walk.

4. The Story. Like I said before, the story isn't good. Now, I read that it's filled with metaphors. The Beginner's Guide is also filled with metaphors. But in The Beginner's Guide, the story is good enough to make me want to know them. That makes replaying the game fun and interesting. But here, I honestly don't care. The story is bad to begin with, and that makes me just not care enough to bother to replay it. Also, the story has these seemingly random bits that are out of order, and are just dumb. The one that sticks out the most is the ending, in which [spoiler] you're driving on a motorcycle with a girl that loves you. You have to press e to continue, and when you do that she looks at you, and you get hit by a van, and then you switch into a car that gets hit a van. [/spoiler] It's just stupid. I bet this is some metaphor, but as I mentioned above, I don't care enough to bother to look into it.

Overall, I'd give it a 4/10. The settings are pretty good, and the soundtract is fantastic, but the 4 points I mention above really ruins the experience. This is the type of game where you buy it, play it, the return it. You're better off watching it on youtube.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995048523', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1498322612}
review: Коротко и концетрированно! Даже если ничего не понял, получил кучу эмоций. Думаю одна из игр, которой вдохновлялись авторы Virginia.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970887687', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 74, 'last_played': 1473884221}
review: Thirty Flights of Loving is an essay in how to tell a story in first-person video games. It's a prime example of show-don't-tell. If you are ever so slightly interested in how a videogame should tell a story to it's player, play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198126092475', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 7, 'last_played': 1523069786}
review:
Remember back in school, when the English teacher made us study a movie, or a book, then made us write poetry about that subject? Then, there was always the one person who got way into the piece we studdied, and couldn't be quiet about the "deeper meaning" of it? So they wrote some extemely exoteric piece that the teacher praised for its "insight into the theme", and the "understanding of the circumstances"? And, when they were forced to read it out loud to the class, people just ignored that person, because it made absolutely no sense? 

This game is that poem. And this poem is wonderful.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117638960', 'num_games_owned': 907, 'num_reviews': 244, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 111, 'last_played': 1630545222}
review: Me intriga ver Thirty Flights of Loving indicado como Neutro na Steam, mas entendo que não é um jogo para todos. Ele é um curto jogo focado na história onde você é um espião. O que torna esse jogo único é a maneira como conta sua história: sem diálogo nem textos de exposição, apenas pelo cenário e por visões/flashbacks/flashforwards. O jogo é muito estilizado, com cenas que não tentam ser realistas, mas têm seu estilo próprio. A trilha sonora também é muito boa, dando um ar de 007 ao jogo. Pode ser considerado um walking simulator, sendo que realmente tudo o que você faz nesse jogo é andar. Aparentemente ele é o sétimo jogo da franquia Citizen Abel, porém 5 deles são mods de Quake 2 e Half-life. O sexto jogo, porém, se chama Gravity Bone, e pode ser jogado a partir desse jogo, ou gratuitamente na internet. Gravity Bone possui mais ação que Thirty Flights of Loving, e também acho que vale a pena conferir, principalmente sendo de graça. Não vou mentir: 10 reais acho um pouco caro pelo jogo. Mas, se tiver em uma promoção, não deixe de conferir esse jogo, se o que escrevi acima te agradou. E se você gosta de saber mais sobre o desenvolvimento do jogo, tem um comentário do desenvolvedor que achei excelente, onde ele fala sobre como mostrar o que o jogador deve fazer apenas pelo design do mapa.

author: {'steamid': '76561198073404675', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 251, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1497721139}
review: That was definitely an experience unlike any other I've had, but I don't think that was a good thing.  I play a lot of "walking simulator" genre games, but there wasn't enough depth to this one (mostly due to its incredibly short runtime of about 20 minutes if you're pokey about finishing) to warrant the lack of gameplay features that come with the territory here.  I didn't hate the game by any means, but I think if I hadn't gotten it in a bundle deal, I would have felt like I had wasted my money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002819597', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1497644879}
review: This game was a whole lot of nothing. No reason to care for the story, no real gameplay, only thing it's got going for it is the graphics and even then it didn't really take advantage of much. Not worth getting for free, let alone paying money for it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198061592060', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1497426535}
review:
This game is just a horrible stinking mess. 

It's trying to tell a story about a criminal trio in an evil futuristic world and their downfall or something. But squeezing that kind of interesting scenario down to a 10 minute walking simulator just doesn't work at all. The characters are lifeless, the environments are uninteresting and you need to pay alot of attention to details to even figure out what's going on.

Next up, the technical side. I don't know who is responsible for this but making a game in 2012 using the Quake 2 Engine (1997) is just plain stupid. As a result of that, the game looks really bad and it crashed three times (and that during 10 minutes of playtime). It's trying to achieve a certain "artstyle" but with its blocky characters and pixelated textures (probably made in MS Paint from the look of it) it just doesn't look good at all. Controls and sound aren't very good either.

Also, for no apparent reason, there's a two minute section at the end about Bernoulli and how planes fly (what?!).

Maybe I'm just not smart enough to understand this "game" but I've played my fair share of "walking simulators" and there are way better ones out there than this. Don't waste your money on this!!! (I got it for practically free and I still feel ripped off)

author: {'steamid': '76561198049433567', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1497407794}
review: Like probably most others, I got this game as part of a bundle, the "Humble Freedom Bundle" and would never have dreamed of dropping $5 on a thirty minute game with minecraft style graphics. For a game that I got as part of a massive bundle that I knew absolutely nothing about and was not one of the draws (games like The Witness and Stardew Valley were also in the bundle which were the main draws), I found this game pleasant enough. There are two games here, "Thirty Flights of Loving" and something something bone. "Thirty Flights of Loving" is not a losable game, more a walking simulator that is meant to evoke an action movie with silly block heads. It is cute and short enough that it can't be said to wear out its welcome. The other is a bit more of a game, but has a silly part with jumping on flags that should be the sort of challenge you'd expect, but after the walking simulator of Thirty Flights it was a bit jarring. On the whole, is it worth it to install, play for 30 minutes, and be done? Sure.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984622714', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1497130278}

author: {'steamid': '76561198057376104', 'num_games_owned': 631, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1496819463}

author: {'steamid': '76561198178503003', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 44, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1496801589}
review: Um. Not sure what to say about this one. It's not really a game. It's more of a short story, except that it's not really a short story, it's more like the impression of a story. Not a terribly good story, mind you. Imagine a few minecraft people, with guns that you can hold but never shoot, some sort of half-baked love story, except written by someone who doesn't know how to write a story. The only interesting game mechanic was the ability to peel and eat an orange. The rest of the gameplay was disjointed, confusing and just not fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198087220782', 'num_games_owned': 778, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1496801586}

author: {'steamid': '76561198058972693', 'num_games_owned': 1665, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1496695354}

author: {'steamid': '76561198014698888', 'num_games_owned': 924, 'num_reviews': 240, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1496450193}
review:
This game is terrible.  You experience a few disjointed scenes completely out of order.  The game somewhat gives you an idea of what happened, but the awkward pacing and lack of details does not provide a satisfying finish.  In fact, the game ended before I ever really caught on to what was happening.  I replayed the game with Developer Commentary enabled, and all that did was explain design challenges, not any aspect of the plot.  At one point the commentary explained how the rapid scene shifting is meant to be deliberately confusing.  Well, congratulations, you succeeded at making an awful game.

Gravity Bone is a bit better than Thirty Flights of Loving, but not by much.  At least Gravity Bone seems to have a plot, even if the reasons for your actions are never explained.  Most of the actions you perform in Gravity Bone make sense, but it simply doesn't provide enough depth to the gameplay to be worthwhile.  Also, the part where you have to jump onto flags is quite annoying and could have been removed or made easier.

Save an hour of your time and ignore these games.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972498276', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1496385124}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062767576', 'num_games_owned': 594, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1487898653}
review: The main game has 0 gameplay, but after you finish the main part (which is more of a story than anything) go through to the end and you will unlock the prequel, Gravity Bone, which is a fun and random spy thriller. Please, please walk through the first part so you can play the Gravity Bone, it changed my mind about this title.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072070195', 'num_games_owned': 686, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1495298143}

author: {'steamid': '76561197994095004', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1495317159}
review: This is an interesting... thing? But it's not really a game. You don't do anything, or discover things, you just kind of see things. It doesn't even really tell a story. It feels like the back-of-the-book summary of a game, not something that should cost money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009405448', 'num_games_owned': 404, 'num_reviews': 112, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1495290761}
review:
I got this game included in a Humble Bundle. I googled how long the game was (less than an hour),  so I thought I'd play it to feel good about getting a game off my backlog.

It's an artsy, story driven gamewith minimal gameplay - you push W a lot, and occasionally you push E to open a door nob or something. There's no real combat, or much in the way of puzzles. Should you play it depends entirely on how much you like quirky experimental games, and how much it is worth to you. I like those sorts of things, so I'm glad I played it.

This game is a sequel of sorts to Gravity Bone, a game that is available for free from the developer's website. (It is also available through this game, just push ESC anytime during the story).  You are a secret spy on a mission. The story is told in little snippets - walk around a corner and boom, you are in a different place and time in the story. It's fun, it has a bit of humor.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067494330', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 211, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1680638576}
review: Flipping brilliant and I'm not even sure why. A few strange scenes out of chronological order, seamlessly spliced together as you walk around the world. Loved it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197995241096', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1494908109}
review:
I enjoy games that don't give you overt direction. It enables the player to explore and feel like they're making the game their own, with subtle hints from the level design & introduction of gameply elements to help smooth out the difficulty curve.

However, I have no idea what Thirty Flights of Loving is about. I don't even know if I've finished the game. I'm not going to comb through the game to try to find out, and I don't think I should need to look it up online. The whole thing is a confusing mess. The minecraft-but-worse graphics style is not compelling, and nothing about the gameplay is interesting. 

Definitely not worth $5. But, if you really want to see what's up with this game, wait until it's part of an indie bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998639066', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1345878000}

review: I don't normally review games. I got this as part of a Humble Bundle. I played the game for 11 minutes and I believe I saw everthing. It was lovingly and painstakingly made, but very, very short. If I'd paid a full 5 or 10 dollars, I'd be real salty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198007107051', 'num_games_owned': 552, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1493664936}
review: This game should have been free. I appreciate the jump-cuts to different points in the "story", but there's not enough in it. I never found a reason to care in the 20 minutes of the game. A cool experiment, not a game to be charged for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025093564', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1385739119}

author: {'steamid': '76561198118631560', 'num_games_owned': 382, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1493567655}
review: Thirty Flights of Loving is a very short, very linear walking simulaotr that will take you around 10-20 minutes to complete. The story is very pretentious and does very little to convey any substance or meaning, there is virtually no gameplay, and the animations are poorly made. The aesthetic design and music are nice however, and the game has some great visual story telling methods. The biggest problem with this game is the fact that it costs 5 dollars. If this was free it would be another story. But for that price it isn't worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072553411', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1493429438}
review:
What a game!
I can see why this has mixed reviews. The game itself is more of a short walking sim, with everything happening around you. However, the story, although very non-linear, is fantastic. So much happens in such a short amount of time, it takes a bit to figure out what's going on (and what you don't know), and then it's over.
Includes a dev commentary and the devs free game, which has a similar aesthetic and story but a different style of gameplay. I recommend playing them both if you enjoyed one or the other.

author: {'steamid': '76561198128590698', 'num_games_owned': 761, 'num_reviews': 89, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1483221503}

author: {'steamid': '76561198013361872', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1491706369}
review:
Recieved this game as part of the Humble Freedom Bundle.

Gotta say, it's very short, with no instruction. I spent longer wandering around the first area drinking maple drink (or was I just picking it up? No one knows, least of all the player.)

I'm all for visual novels, even those with limited interaction, but this one was painfully short, with so little story that even the title of the game didn't make sense.

Go check out their first game, which you can play for free. Who knows, maybe someone other than me will understand and enjoy what they're trying to do here.

(I must admit, peeling the orange was oddly satisfying.)

author: {'steamid': '76561198045136299', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1491447470}
review:
Thirty Fights of Loving is an abstract, explorative adventure game in which you take on the role of a member of a group of criminals living in a prohibition and police state. You simply wander through a series of environments, occasionally interacting with things, and finding yourself whisked away to another time point. It's not linear and it's not long - which is probably my main issue with it. It's not long enough for those hooks to matter - 5-10 minutes after asking those questions it's over. But that brings me to the part I liked about it - I liked that it left you to interpret/fill in the story, which admittedly won't be everyone's cup of tea.

As for actual recommendations - some people will love it and think it's a brilliant little piece of art, others will hate it and find it pretentious. I, personally, didn't mind it.. but I'm not sure I'd be happy if I paid for it outright (got it in a bundle). Which is why I'm not recommending it. :/ If you're not sure whether or not it's for you, I'd recommend waiting until it's on sale or in a bundle, otherwise you *may* feel cheated.

author: {'steamid': '76561198035661073', 'num_games_owned': 1710, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1490309678}
