author: {'steamid': '76561198044437357', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1490221146}
review:
I'm all for games being as long as they need to be. Not every game needs to be a a 10 hour epic or 50+ hour open world game. A 2 hour game can sometimes tell a great story just as well and lends itself to tight and focused gameplay.

With this game I thought I was in some sort of extended flashback introduction the whole time. When I got to the end I thought that the intro had drug on a little too long and behaps spoiled its plot a little too much, but no, what I thought was a transition to the start of the proper game was the end of the game entirely. Even when I took my time turning around and poking into dark empty corners the whole 'experince' took me less than 30 minutes. I was left feeling like I had played a demo. There are short games and there are artistic experments that should fall under freeware. This, in my mind, falls into the latter.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049720139', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1492018184}
review: In the first playthrough I feel very confused playing this. Seeing it as more of a interactive visual experiment it is quite interesting. I would recommend this as part of a bundle for a very low cost, solely as content is very limited (perhaps 10 minutes for a playthrough).

author: {'steamid': '76561197993266228', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 91, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1489967094}
review:
Score: 0 / 10
Price/Value: Zero.
Time: 10 minutes
Difficulty: N/A

This is the first zero I have given out; I'm not sure how this was a cult smash or received so well at it's launch...but here we go.

Thirty Flights of loving is a series of flashes or flashbacks surrounding three people possibly planning some form of heist. These flashes are frequent, give little to no information and dump you out of the game in ten minutes. There isn't any purpose, goal or even story really being told. The artistry is nothing to write home about and the soundtrack mediocre. 

Do not spend money on this at any price. Should you receive this for free, find a better use for those ten minutes of your life.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970519156', 'num_games_owned': 867, 'num_reviews': 186, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1489963268}
review: Mostly dumb. It's an interesting experimental peice, but it's not interactive in any meaningful way, it's really short, and it's purposefully obtuse, which makes it feel a bit pretentious.

author: {'steamid': '76561198067121286', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 22, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1489960021}
review: I did not know whether to vote no and praise, or to vote yes and criticize. Unless you are into games as a medium and the exploration of new artistic approaches, do not buy (if you got it free, as in a bundle, no risk there). New ideas are always welcome, so I say nice try and hope to see more stuff in this spirit in the future. But this one did not resonate with me, although at some very specific points they managed to create an interesting atmosphere. Without a doubt, the best this game does is respecting the player as a clever person.

author: {'steamid': '76561198028127856', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1500695907}
review:
Mechanically there isn't much to 30 Flights of Loving or Gravity Bone, just WASD movement and an action button. But like The Stanley Parable or Thomas Was Alone, this is the kind of thing you pick up not for the gameplay but for a game where the developer is trying something weird and different and beautiful. It might not work 100%, but it will certainly stand out from almost everything else you have in your game library.

30 Flights of Loving starts off as a spy story and to say anything else will spoil the story. The rest of the game may be short, but also strange, bittersweet and I thoroughly enjoyed it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198109883351', 'num_games_owned': 1814, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1489840731}
review:
The fact that I played it to the end was testament to what is a very weird narrative experiment.

There is limited interaction and no directions (besides things you can touch, walking and looking) and yet it told a somewhat coherent story.

I'm not sure if I'm bewildered or impressed, a bit of both. Not sure I would be happy if I paid full price for it but as part of the Humble Bundle I’m glad I played it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072131218', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 39, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1489869148}
review: I am confused

author: {'steamid': '76561198075927829', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 114, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 35, 'last_played': 1489768368}
review:
好我玩了(或說看了)這個遊戲
嗯我知道這是什麼東西:這個是標準的那種「假裝很有深度很前衛的藝術作品」

簡單總結劇情:第一章你是某個犯罪分子，跟其他兩個很醜的大頭做了許多犯罪
然後好像玩家跟其中一個女成員談戀愛之類的，反正結局主角死了
遊戲中加入很多閃回，好像有些人覺得很有創意，我只覺得乾我屁事

第二章主角是個特務(殺手?)反正就是做了一些帶入感很差的任務
中間我卡關，跑去看了別人的影片流程(對我沒打完)，總之就是要做一個天外飛來一筆的超難跳躍
以抵達其他地區
然後被某個女人幹掉，給了一個莫名的閃回
然後就結束了

你知道嗎?我一點也不care發生三小，我只想知道這個作品到底想幹嘛
於是我看了別人作的劇情解釋，總之就是有一些情感鳩葛，還有一些反諷和藏在裡面的深刻情感...屁啦

它，就是，很爛好嗎。
拜託，除非你是那種看「一個男人憂傷的在電梯裡緩緩上升，搭配哀傷的音樂」也會覺得好棒的觀眾
否則的話別買這遊戲也別玩這遊戲，因為你只會得到被浪費了20分鐘的體驗
這種假裝藝術的鬼東西應該要被抵制，因為它不但浪費你在其中的時間，還浪費你事後查資料試圖搞清楚到底發生啥事的時間
我覺很後悔玩了這個遊戲(HB包附的)真他X的為何要讓我的遊戲庫有這個東西，我還要被自以為是的藝術式表現給噁心到
真是夠了，給我去我遊戲庫中的「很雷類」去!垃圾遊戲!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006486215', 'num_games_owned': 3375, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 48, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 48, 'last_played': 1489163082}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving feels like a pitch for a bigger game. Before things could get interesting, it's over.

I'd like to point out right away that the game did not like my computer. The game crashed multiple times after trying to change settings, and I managed to somehow die during the first jump cut...and then crash. Setting the game's executable to Windows 98 compatibility mode and setting the resolution options as launch parameters seemed to fix it.

I do quite like the art style, and the music and sound effects are excellent. It's just a shame that there's not too much of any of it.

That's not to say what's there is bad. I like the general presentation of the story, for the most part. Due to the jump cuts, it can be unclear on the exact order of events that occur. You're missing parts of the story, and what's there is out of order, but piecing it together isn't ridiculously complicated. That said, I can understand why it might confuse some.

As I said before, though, it feels like a pitch to raise money for a longer version of the game. I want more details on the story. What went wrong with the job they were on, and what was the job they were doing, anyway? You have to give a reason for people to care. A summary of a story never has the impact that the full story does.

My feelings about Gravity Bone, the prequel to this (and which is included in this package), can be summed up in pretty much the same way, with one additional complaint: the gameplay. While Thirty Flights of Loving is mostly a walking simulator with very limited activity, Gravity Bone has a few items that you pick up and carry in your inventory. While having  interactivity is fine in a walking simulator, Gravity Bone makes the mistake of making what limited interactivity is in the game repetitive and unenjoyable, and honestly could have been done better with either reduced/smarter use of it, or near complete removal of it.

If Blendo Games decides to come back to this universe, I'd really like a more fleshed out experience next time. I don't mind the linearity or the absurd-yet-serious tone, but there's just not enough here to justify your time or your money.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054278258', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 52, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 52, 'last_played': 1489095991}
review:
I did not enjoy this game. It's just a bunch of confusing rooms and poorly-animated character interactions. The environments and graphics were ugly, even if the art style is meant to be simplistic. The gameplay seems to be split into 2 stories: Thirty Flights of Loving and Gravity Bone. TFOL is just exploring various environments; there is almost no interaction by the player other than walking. Gravity Bone has more interactivity, with items to use and quests to complete, but it is still extremely linear and vague in terms of what is happening.

I do give this game credit for attempting to tell a story without voice or dialogue, but it was executed terribly. Maybe I just suck at infering things, but I could not follow what sort of story this game was trying to tell.

author: {'steamid': '76561197999546836', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 28, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 28, 'last_played': 1489013036}
review:
This is at its best an ~*artistic*~ walking simulator.

This is at its worst a diminutive walking simulator.

This was an effort by its designer (apparently) to engage in storytelling without typical narrative techniques, ie. Voiceovers, random data files, etc. Commendable, but borrowing from cinema isn't anything new. Games have borrowed from cinema repeatedly.

What this game doesn't really spend much, if any, time doing is having the actual structure of the gameplay inform us of story. At one point, in his commentary, the designer explains that he used a characters acceptance of our taking an orange for ourselves to show that this was a space we belonged in. But in a game with such sparse interaction, we as players can't tell the difference between a character's acceptance of our actions, and lazy coding that failed to include consequences for our actions.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004120455', 'num_games_owned': 799, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 61, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1489130984}
review:
Why someone might do it, I have no idea. Thirty Flights of Loving is a videogame immitation of French New Wave cinema. Along with Gravity Bone (which is included) the experience takes about half an hour—far less time than an artsy movie. Emotionally, it carries a similar impact perhaps because you are an actor in the piece. While there is no danger of making a wrong choice, there is a sense of peril. Even though it is impossible to explore the characters, there's an impression of romance and friendship. A simple plot is complicated by a trick of chronological confusion, but I still feel it has added meaning somehow.

On the whole, this is a game you play in order to think, talk and write about later. It probably deserves a replay after you've had time to contemplate. (I haven't done that yet.) In addition, I'm looking forward to the commentary option. If you are into that sort of thing, there are far worse things to spend your money on.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049106163', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1488243431}
review:
Despite the short gameplay, it was quite an interesting one, especially with the Development Commentary. The commentary itself showed the short experience in a new light, allowing me better appreciate the work and effort that went into it, not to mention how certain elements came to be.

I was really hoping for a longer narritive, but its good for what it is. In any sense, with what the game provides in the time given, it really did get me interested in the story itself.

Side note: Also, I'm curious to how this game got involved with the Humble Freedom Bundle. Either way, I appreciate the fact that Blendo Games was involved with the effort through this specific game being provided in the bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969862748', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 53, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 53, 'last_played': 1488102427}
review:
The game has a decent art style, but absolutely no depth - and is only about 5 minutes long. There are no secrets to discover, no longevity. 

The story telling style is interesting - but just falls really short.

There is developers commentary where the developer speaks of his team and the production process. This would be interesting - but in all honesty, the game feels like a high school project.

I received this game as part of a humble bundle with the expectation that it would be something akin to games such as Jazz Punk (which is awesome). It's not. I would not recommend buying this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198195454010', 'num_games_owned': 1047, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1488047482}

author: {'steamid': '76561198001180221', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 284, 'playtime_forever': 30, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1488043620}
review:
GLANCE RECOMMENDATION: 39% YES / [u][b]61% NO[/b][/u]

[h1]GOOD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Visual style is clean and inviting.
[*]Soundtrack is stellar and adds to the campy spy vibe they're going for.
[/list]

[h1]NEUTRAL[/h1]
[list]
[*]The story is unfortunately spastic and uninteresting, which really untangles this experience. I can see what they're going for, but too often does it jump around haphazardly and, if you look at the story overall, it's not very inventive. It's incredibly run-of-the mill, snack-sized spy tales.
[/list]

[h1]BAD[/h1]
[list]
[*]Controls feel bad which, won't be a problem for most of the game since you barely have agency, but WILL matter if you attempt Gravity Bone where first person platforming is required. If you're wondering what it feels like to have a 9 minute game grind to a sudden halt, you'll find it at the flag poles.
[*]Quite frankly there just isn't much for you to do. In fact there's barely a need for the player to be there. Beyond buying this to support the developer, I honestly don't think any player will have any meaningful experience outside of just watching someone play this through a video site.
[/list]

[h1]SUMMARY[/h1]
More art than an actual game, I just can't recommend people pay for this if they're wanting to PLAY a game. Absolutely buy this if you're wanting to support the dev and you liked the story after watching a video, but I doubt you'd have any different experiences playing this yourself.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053777519', 'num_games_owned': 2609, 'num_reviews': 124, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1487968254}
review:
[h1]20 minutes[/h1]
That's all it takes to beat this game. There are two "stories" you can play where both are you running around doing nothing. The game is a little like telltale games except the fact that you don't do anything of signifigance in this game but running around. It shows that the developer has put love into this game and spend his time with it but it is really nothing great. The music is half tom and jerry and half ruining my ears. The artstyle is clunky which is fine but i wouldn't compliment it. and the gameplay is just running around pressing E once in a while and that's it. There really isn't alot to this game and you're probably better off watching some show for 20 minutes. I did find the game a little fun playing but with such a high price and so little and boring gameplay is it not worth it at all. If there were added some more story and maybe improved the gameplay could it be closer to worth it but even then would it probably not be near worth the 5 bucks.

author: {'steamid': '76561198124475637', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1487367403}
review:
It is a walking sim. Tagging it as an adventure is kinda misleading because there's no real progression. I mean, I played this on a whim and I was ready for a short experience and I was thinking it would have some nuance to it, but as far as I can tell it's a one trick pony that feels like something I'd find on one of those "free browser games" websites. Sorry but five bucks feels a bit high for something that last less than the time it takes me to finish my morning coffee. 

tl;dr: If you have five bucks to blow and 20 minutes to kill, this is a great way to kill two birds with one stone.

Edit: I think it actually took me longer to write this review then it did to beat the game :/

author: {'steamid': '76561198071355683', 'num_games_owned': 518, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 82, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 82, 'last_played': 1487722517}
review:
I probably spent too much time on this game, but I wanted to look at every detail. I played it once through, then played it with the developer commentary, and then played Gravity Bone. I don't really understand why everyone is so upset with it being short. After the developer commentary, I understand it a great deal more and appreciate it. This game was originally scrapped because it wasn't working out, and the developer knew that and even points out a bunch of the flaws and explains why he did what he did. It was only a prototype and was brought back to life to help a kickstarter. Nothing wrong with that. No, it wasn't game of the year material. But it was fun for what it was. I also enjoyed Gravity Bone. 

Perception is largely based in expectation. 

I wouldn't pay too much for it, but if you're a fan of indie games and interested in how they're made, I'd recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044564432', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1490512454}
review:
Granted...I got this through the Humble Freedom Bundle.
So I won't be picky with the quality of the game through that.
But I will still review it as if I paid for the full retail asking price.
Now...I cannot recommend this game. Why? It can be beaten within 5 minutes.
I have personally used a timer to see how fast you can really beat the game.
I get that $4.99 is not a whole lot and you shouldn't expect a whole lot out of it.
Yet, there are other games at that same exact price that have a lot more content.
This "Game" has little to no interaction aside from being a walking simulator.
And the "Amazing story" that I kept hearing about was confusing and all over the place.
The animation is horribly lazy. Yet again, that's to be expected for a game at such a low cost.
This game really should have been free.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996017641', 'num_games_owned': 2811, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 55, 'last_played': 1487630952}
review:
[h1]Was geht hier eigentlich ab?![/h1]

Thirty Flights of Loving und Gravity Bone sind sicher keine wirklichen Spiele mit viel Spiel, sondern mehr "Waling Simulator" oder "FPEX (First Person Exploration)" Spiele, also Erkundings/Erlebniss Spiele in denen man eine Geschichte erlebt indem man durch die Gegend läuft und mit Objekten Interagiert.

In vielen Spielen funktioniert das dadurch, das man meist eine Geschichte durch viele Papier Schnippsel oder andere Sachen wie zum Beispiel Telefonate mitbekommt. 
[b]Thirty Flights of Loving macht in dem Punkt aber einiges anders.[/b]

Wir bekommen die Geschichte nur durch einige Level Umgebungen und hin und wieder etwas Text mit und müssen uns fast die Komplette Geschichte selber zusammen denken. 
Das kann einige schon abschrecken. Mich selbst hat es anfangs auch etwas gestört, vor allem da sich die beiden Titel völlig verschieden angefühlt haben, was die Geschichts Schnippsel angeht.

Mir hat das ganze beim ersten durchspielen auch etwas Kopfzerbrechen bereitet warum das nun so passiert ist oder die Geschichte so ausging. 
Danach habe ich mir das ganze mit den Entwickler Kommentaren angesehen, diese sind leider nur Textboxen die man im eigentlichen Spiel findet, daraufhin wurde mir einiges klar. Leider bleiben nach wie vor einige mehr oder weniger kleine Fragen offen.

Außerdem ist nicht ganz klar oder zumindest mir nicht, wie Gravity Bone sich in das ganze einfügt. Ich habe gehört das es vor Thirty Flights of Loving spielen soll, es wirkt aber wiederrum so als würde es danach spielen oder gar nichts mit dem Spiel zu tun haben. 

Wer abgedrehte Spiele ohne wirkliches Spiel sondern mehr mit Erkundung und "Was geht hier gerade ab?" Momenten mag, kann sich das Spiel vielleicht einmal ansehen. Dazu muss ich aber sagen, das ich das ganze (Thirty Flights of Loving/Gravity Bone und Thirty Flights of Loving mit Entwickler Kommentare Lesen) in ca. 0,9 Std. durch hatte. 

[b]Daher sollten alle die sich unsicher sind, vor allem wegen der Länge und der Geschichte des Spiels, zumindest ein Video zu Gravity Bone ansehen, das ganze spiegelt zumindest die Art des Spiels etwas wieder, wobei Thirty Flights of Loving noch weniger Spiel bietet als Gravity Bone, in letzterem hat man zumindest noch einige Interaktion mit Gegenständen. [/b]

author: {'steamid': '76561198039309797', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1487711859}
review:
Not because it's short, but because it's a technical mess.

Also the game is £4 for 15 minutes. Would be great, but Gravity bone seemed to make out like the followup would be a game, not an interactive movie.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103180992', 'num_games_owned': 538, 'num_reviews': 75, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1487615967}
review: Ummm I don't get it

author: {'steamid': '76561198015196676', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 39, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 103, 'last_played': 1487670075}
review:
I really liked the presentation and pacing of this game. The way the narrative is presented really worked for me. The soundtrack cues come in perfectly. The story is cute as well. I don't get the emotional impact some writers talk about, but thats more of a my problem than it is the game's problem. Stories resonate for each of us differently, and maybe if I were in different circumstances it might have knocked a feeling or two loose. Who knows. I did enjoy it's sense of whimsy and adventure.

There are lots of great little details if you care to look for them. I did care, and played through two times, then another time with the commentary. One of the nice things about short, dense games is that the investment time is low and I can easily explore them again and see new things. In larger games I get choice paralysis sometimes, where my desire to experience every bit causes me to get distracted when something is actually happening but oh no there was that hallway back there I didnt look in what if I missed some sick loots...

The previus game in the series, Gravity Bone is included. While it's free from Blendogames.com, having it within the same package but as the 3rd option under the "Career" menu invited me to play it last and in succession. I did and appreciated the design choices re: failure states in Thirty Flights even more. I found it interesting to compare and contrast the previous work so quickly after completing the successor. Sorta like binge watching a movie series.

This game is lovely and I recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197993196569', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487468546}

author: {'steamid': '76561198054604307', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487460908}
review: Thirty Flights of Loving is a boring, pretentious and hardly interactive "game." The story is convoluted and no gameplay exists. Even the developer commentary is just ramblings about how the creator put lights in a corner you walk past in the first 30 seconds of gameplay. I wouldn't recommend anyone ever wasting their time on this, even if it was free.

If you enjoy it, props to you, but I just didn't find myself pulled in by its narrative.

review:

It seems that the game was meant to be played in one sitting because after I make my changes to resolution, textures, etc, it will crash the next time i press ESC. author: {'steamid': '76561198153789822', 'num_games_owned': 235, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 22, 'last_played': 1505411134}

author: {'steamid': '76561198029371348', 'num_games_owned': 455, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487350085}

author: {'steamid': '76561198018991849', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 67, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 67, 'last_played': 1487340740}
review:
TFOL is a brilliant little game that challenges the current principles of narration. It's a bold and interesting experiment and the result is an endearing story centered around three outlaws who battle against an unfair government.

Yes it is short but I found the game thoroughly enjoyable and well worth the time and price. Special mention to the soundtrack which really makes the game imo. They even included a second game that is as long as TFOL (15 minutes) and just as good.

author: {'steamid': '76561197989784506', 'num_games_owned': 2176, 'num_reviews': 353, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1487329268}
review:
"not a game" "don't buy", yeah yeah i get these opinions.
But you know what? I bloody enjoyed playing this game.

+ : graphics, gameplay, story in achronological order, characters

- : yes. People here are totally right. It is SHORT. Literally 10 minutes of gameplay. But the gameplay is intense. And it is expensive too and not worth the full price

I got it in a bundle so that is massive thumbs up. If it were free, i am sure it would have had Overwhelmingly positive rating. But it isn't. Still GG. It is a piece of an art.
Therefore 5+4 (for the order of the story)/10, would learn the Bernoulli's principle again

author: {'steamid': '76561197998238193', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 55, 'playtime_forever': 33, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 33, 'last_played': 1487291465}
review: I'm glad I got it for free.  Not to say there's anything wrong with the game, per se, it's just more of a proof of concept or a short visual movie than a game.  It would have made more sense on YouTube or as a free download, not a $5 purchase.  I encourage them to keep making more games/art, but to charge appropriately.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043891476', 'num_games_owned': 1594, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1487284848}
review: I got this from a Humble Bundle. It would be nice if they made a real game, the aesthetics and the story it's good. It's a 10/15 minute story, almost a walk simulator. The good thing is that, if you bought it, you can ask for a refund.

author: {'steamid': '76561198013082079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1487283760}
review: This game is like 4 minutes long. Not worth buying

author: {'steamid': '76561198043858492', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 24, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 24, 'last_played': 1487275941}
review:
I loved Gravity Bone, this didn't do the same for me.

While I am usually all for a game being as long as it needs, this game is too short. I don't think it properly tells its story within the 5 mins it takes to complete (longer including replaying it due to crashes) and would benefit from being longer. All it manages to tell is a shell of a story, the elevator pitch of a story, but not a story itself.

As for the crashing, how in the world can a game based upon the quake engine which is generally stable crash so often? The game is 5 mins long and has no gameplay outside of walking, no choices to be made outside of small insignificant enviornoment interactions, I can understand that bugs occasionally happen, but I am not the only one reporting issues. Its not like this game will have tens of thausands of lines of code on top of what the game engine provides, how is it not stable, after being on the market for this long?

Funnily enough when I got to the end I thought it was doing a fake ending, little did I know that was literally it.

I got this game with the Humble Freedom Bundle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103472572', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1487259275}
review: Got it from the Humble Freedom Bundle and honestly this game is not worth 5 bucks. It's really uninteractive, the word game does barely apply since all you do is move around and you interact with objects for like 10 times before the game is over after about 10 minutes.  The artstyle is rather lazy in my opinion. The only redeeeming factor of 30 flights of loving is its non linear storytelling which keeps you somewhat interested in these 20 minutes as you try to figure out how the pieces of action you see fit in a timeline.

author: {'steamid': '76561198050003442', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 30, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1487237366}
review:
Extremely short. It isn't fun. And the story they try to tell is extremely vague.

tl;dr Not fun. Meh story. Extremely short. Not worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054914250', 'num_games_owned': 599, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1487153316}
review:
This game definitely isn't for everyone, you might enjoy this game if you like:

Exploring you surroundings,
Vague story telling often forcing you to make your own interpretations,
Unique minimalistic graphic styles,
Stories that often leave you with unanswered questions.

I personally enjoyed the game even though it was honestly more of a walking simulator than a game. 
If you're not sure that you want to spend the 5$ on this game I would recommend you watch someone on YouTube play the game instead.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042913585', 'num_games_owned': 871, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1487223022}
review:
I beat it in 8 minutes

Updating this two years later, this game is really just supposed to be an art piece. In doing that, its exceptional, but the creator seems to forget theyre trying to market it as a video game, which is the opposite of what Thirty Flights of Loving is. Its interesting and creates an enrapturing image of a somewhat stereotypical action movie narrative, but I'm completely unable to understand what makes it deserving of a price tag of any kind.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027271891', 'num_games_owned': 1114, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 13, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 13, 'last_played': 1487219124}

author: {'steamid': '76561198065913006', 'num_games_owned': 531, 'num_reviews': 105, 'playtime_forever': 10, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 10, 'last_played': 1487141896}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025420508', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1487042832}
review:
Thirty Flights Of Loving is short.

Thirty Flights Of Loving will take you roughly 30 minutes to complete, front to back.

Thirty Flights of Loving is cheap.

Thirty Flights of Loving will cost you $5 maximum.

Thirty Flights of Loving is an intense, first person spy thriller that utilizes environmental storytelling and fast jump cuts to tell you a story quicker and punchier than any medium or game before it.

Thirty Flights of Loving is good, and worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044348398', 'num_games_owned': 2249, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487116008}

author: {'steamid': '76561198008591010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 35, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1640910402}
review: I'm gonna say right off the bat, although I enjoy and recommend this game, I got it in a humble bundle and I'd be REALLY hard-pressed to say it's worth the asking 5$.  That being said; this game is less a "walking simulator" and more of a short film in the form of a game.  This feels like a lucid dream, and absolute trip.  And that in and of itself is what makes it a worthwhile story.  Although it's very hard to say anything without spoiling it, I'd say the fun "game" aspect is really just trying to figure out what the hell it's about.  Have you ever watched a bizarre psychological thriller and wondered throughout the film "wtf is this even supposed to be about?!?!" This game essentially is like that, but is a bit less patient and doesn't really keep you guessing that long.  Overall I did highly enjoy it, even if my steam log literally says "13 minutes played."  It is, simply put, a quality story in a trippy environment.  The ending is abrupt however, and unless you got it on sale or in a bundle, I can't imagine not being disappointed if I spent 5$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047529817', 'num_games_owned': 961, 'num_reviews': 34, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1357113600}

It is nothing but a cute prototype with an interesting story and cool art, but you are MUCH better off going to watch a let's play as there's very little point to this. I can appreciate the idea, but I cannot appreciate that this garbage sells for anything more than $0.20.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998042773', 'num_games_owned': 978, 'num_reviews': 452, 'playtime_forever': 12, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 12, 'last_played': 1487098863}
review:
It is worth the 15 minutes it takes to go through it with development commentary. It is not good to pay any amount of money for it.

They can call it art but they could call it 'my first game project I shipped' and that would apply as well. I am kinda disappointed actually.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018811979', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 8, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1487095960}
review:
***Got it from a humble bundle - not sure i'd be happy if i'd bought it - definitely wouldnt get it at full price.***

It was an interesting, fairly enjoyable 15-20 minutes with some nice areas and small set pieces although im a big walking sim fan so i was always going to like it. 
As always, Chris Reno's music is fantastic and the game was definitely interesting - i even learned a little about aerodynamics and the physics of flight.

Theres almost no gameplay and a lot of story threads dont really get an ending or even make much sense off the bat. 

[h1] I'll tentatively recommend this but only if you're a fan of walking simulators and experimental games, even then not at full price, however i did enjoy it [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197986050898', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1487083611}

author: {'steamid': '76561197993022771', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 187, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1487079795}
review: gravity bone을 추억하며 사기에 너무 짧고 난해다.

author: {'steamid': '76561198049061232', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1487063594}
review:
The most interesting part to this game is the way it approaches to storytelling. And for that matter, it partially is a game and maybe also partially is a meta game, in a sense that it wants to lure you into showing how to tell a story without "telling it" by avoiding dialogues and voice over. 

As a whole though, it isnt much of a game, but rather a concept. Many interesting ideas to be seen and a few very good ones for the photography and some close ups. 

Visually, it has some sort of art style, but the level of detail is overall a bit too low. Sound wise, there are a few bits of soundtrack i quite liked. Maybe there should have been more emphasis on that, and on a more detailed in-game world.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975259789', 'num_games_owned': 870, 'num_reviews': 85, 'playtime_forever': 18, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 18, 'last_played': 1357372800}
review:
I'm sorry, but I don't get this game nor do I understand why so many people rave about it. Although the art direction is certainly unique, it's meant to be more of a fast-paced walking simulator than anything else. Supposedly there is something meta or symbolic about the game and its method of storytelling, but I'll be damned if I can figure out what it is. And the story is so intentionally vague that it's difficult to get anything out of it.

I really did try to get something out of it. I love games that try to do something different and try to approach story-telling from different perspectives. Games like "Dear Esther", "Journey", "Going Home" and so forth were some of the most amazing experiences I've played because of their unique way of getting the story across. But I got nothing out of this game. Nothing.

author: {'steamid': '76561197985900743', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 19, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 19, 'last_played': 1487035128}
review:
Not a game, an art piece.
Crashes a lot if you play with settings...
Get it in a bundle if you can.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000215884', 'num_games_owned': 1415, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1347260400}
review:
As someone who loved the wackiness of Gravity Bone, Thirty Flights was just a disappointment to me. It is still incredibly short, being maybe 15 minutes long... and the plot. Well I'm not even sure what the plot was, beyond being vaguely spy themed and involving a love interest. It just felt like it was missing a few extra key details that would take the plot from "I don't know what happened" to "I'm not [i]certain[/i] what happened, but I have a few strong theories and an overall idea". It didn't seem to understand the difference between "up for intepretation" and just being vague and confusing. There's not a great deal of repay value beyond looking for plot details you may have missed.

I thought I was in for a treat, but I got something with less charm than Gravity Bone, and despite being free no real extra length or production value.

author: {'steamid': '76561197978406355', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 189, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1358755200}
review: Done in 15 minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198091873829', 'num_games_owned': 472, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 115, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 94, 'last_played': 1497288081}
review: This "game" has a unique way of story telling along with a great music and sound effects. One of the greatest art works i have enjoyed.

author: {'steamid': '76561197984587715', 'num_games_owned': 321, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 38, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 38, 'last_played': 1483568846}
review:
It's not like it was poorly made or anything.  The artistic styling is some what charming and it's easy to appreciate how it's able to convey it's story without any spoken dialogue, at least none you can understand anyway.  

Regardless, despite how I dislike how commonly this criticism might be used in general this game just isn't worth any price.  You can complete it in like ten minutes.  Sure, there's a text based commentary but your milage from that really depends on how much you actually care about the base product.  I didn't finish the commentary because I didn't really care, nothing in the story had me infatuated so much that I'd care to learn about the development process.  Nothing about this was really impressive.

There's nothing truly wrong about this game that I could criticize it past having a price tag but that's really because there's just hardly anything here so to speak.  Another artsy walking sim, and there's really nothing inherently wrong with that.  Some truly great ones have been made like the Stanley Parable, but asking for money for this is a bit much.  Otherwise I'd at least be more willing to praise it's merits.

author: {'steamid': '76561198014801466', 'num_games_owned': 295, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 39, 'last_played': 1485143600}
review: Thirty Flights of Loving can be completed in under an hour, but the experience is worth it. This is definitely not a game for everyone, as the style and feel is pretty absurd. If strange atmosphere and an absurdist style sounds appealing, this would be a great experience for you.

review:
Thirty Flights of Loving is an okay game. It has an interesting story to tell and it's brevity helps with the overall feeling of the plot, but it's still just an "okay" game.

Gravity Bone is the previous title in the series, it is included with Thirty Flights of Loving as an extra game, squirreled away within the menus waiting for you to load it up and play. Gravity Bone is _fantastic_ and is the real reason you should consider making this purchase.

author: {'steamid': '76561198147518579', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 254, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 185, 'last_played': 1557269785}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving is a really quirky, but in my opinion, very enjoyable game. The art style is unique, and even without any actual dialogue, the game tells an entire story. The game is pretty short, but it also comes with another game called Gravity Bone. 

Pros
Unique Art Style
Good story
Strange, but in a good way

Cons
It is a very short game
The ending is... weird, not in a great way

author: {'steamid': '76561198155846252', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 91, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 54, 'last_played': 1481678633}
review:
Thirty Flights of Loving is the sequel to the game Gravity Bone from 2008.

It is the perfect game to play when you have a bunch of friends over. Its extreme strangeness and unique humor will leave you all utterly confused. It's not just weird and funny, though. Through its simplistic style, it is able to convey an intriguing and comprehensive story.

If you aren't sure what to expect and don't want to spend $5 on something that may disappoint you, download Gravity Bone. You can download it for free from the developer's website.

If you do buy it, be sure to play through a second time with the developer commentary on. It is fascinating to see how much thought went into the level design, and I have great respect for the developer, Brendon Chung.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010834035', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1361088000}

author: {'steamid': '76561198062813911', 'num_games_owned': 1955, 'num_reviews': 2050, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 30, 'last_played': 1572909200}
review:
[h1] DISCLAIMER: This is a full review, and NOT a first impressions review like all my other reviews, if you want a better full review, then please read better reviews then mine [/h1]

[quote] PLEASE NOTE: I recommended this game with some exceptions, overall if the game did not live up to just a tiny expectation, I would not have recommended it at all, so please read the review carefully if you are thinking of buying/playing this game [/quote]

Thirty Flights of Loving is a game developed by Blendo Games. The game forms part of the Citizen Abel series which also has a prequel known as Gravity Bone which is also include in the game

The game is extremely short, I completed everything the game had to offer in under 30 minutes and that for me is kind of ridiculous. I am not going to mention anything of the story because if I did I would tell you not to buy this game. The game is surprisingly developed on the Quake II and it shows as the game is horribly optimsed for modern systems, expect crashes if you want to play the game at 1920x1080

There are also some sound issues and graphical glitches which hinder the game. Honestly, this game should have been offered for free as what Blendo Games did for Gravity Bone. Honestly, the game is extremely short and I discovered what the game had to offer in a relatively short time. This includes finishing Thirty Flights of Loving, Gravity Bone and playing Thirty Flights of Loving with its developer commentary

Honestly, even for the price the game is offering now, I wouldn't recommend it at all. Wait until it's dirt cheap (which is what I had done) or (although I do not condone it) pirate it and just see what the game has to offer

Otherwise don't bother...

[h1] RECOMMENDED :) [/h1]

author: {'steamid': '76561197980750509', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1473132560}
review:
Check out the developer's first game Gravity Bone for free on their website. If you enjoy that experience, and think its worth 5 dollars then get this. I purchased this expecting it to be a little more in depth than Gravity Bone, but sadly it was not. These aren't so much games as they are interactive cinematic experiences. Clearly influenced by modern film. 

Both experiences show a ton of potential, but are woefully short on content. In the end I think a couple of dollars would be an acceptable price for entry cosnidering Gravity Bone is included with this game as well.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970761123', 'num_games_owned': 2953, 'num_reviews': 896, 'playtime_forever': 31, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 31, 'last_played': 1471843712}
review:
I have spent 31 minutes playing this game, at least half were setting up my computer and trying to make it work. 

This game is... Well to put it bluntly, shit.  A 10 minute game, where the entire "gameplay" is walk from point to point, and that's bad.  The game offers you a use item button, and a inventory system.  I found guns, I couldn't use, oranges that you can peel and eat (for no reason) and ... that's it. 

I can't express how low my opinion of the game, even when the game should be constricting you to a position (riding on a motorcycle, in a plane) you're able to free roam for no reason.  I'm riding on a bike and I can walk to the right or left, and yet still travel at the same speed as the bike, and then the game ends? 

The story is rough.  There's what feels like four scenes, but it doesn't really fit together in any interesting way.  The name of the game makes almost no sense.   And overall there's nothing good to recommend here. 

The only good news is if you buy this game, you can play it and get a refund in the time it takes watch a tv show with out commercials.   But honestly, there's NOTHING here. I can't believe people would recommend a 10 minute game to anyone. 

And btw no this isn't "art" I don't think you can hide behind that, there's games that are art, like Stanley's parable, Gone Home, and The Beginner's guide, and I can have different opinions on them.  This isn't even attempting to be art, it's a cash grab.

author: {'steamid': '76561197990262556', 'num_games_owned': 648, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 123, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 123, 'last_played': 1470328453}
review:
Pubblicata: 28 feb 2014, ore 14:47	
Aggiornata: 1 ago, ore 16:14

28 Febbraio 2014: recensivo questo gioco in maniera molto negativa a causa della mia mente chiusa che riusciva a vedere soltanto dentro la scatola.

Dopo 2 anni, l'ho finalmente rigiocato e devo dire che è un gioco molto strano e particolare. Sicuramente vuole dare un messaggio, anche se non ho ben capito di cosa vuole trattare. La trama sembra essere una spy-story o comunque la storia di questi tre criminali che devono fare un colpo, che sorprendentemente va male. Non si capisce nemmeno chi muore o chi vive, perchè alcuni personaggi muoiono più di una volta...

E' un gameplay lineare che fornisce informazioni attraverso la sola osservazione. Senza dubbio un curioso esperimento che vale la pena di giocare anche solo per farsi un'idea su uno sviluppatore indie che ormai è piuttosto conosciuto e da poco ha fatto uscire il suo nuovo gioco.

E' uno stile unico, accompagnato da una colonna sonora di qualità e da concept ed influenze interessanti.

Un bell'esperimento.

Voto: 7/10


[Chiccha: la mia vecchia recensione di questo gioco... che risale a quando ero ancora un caprone ignorante]

''Non ne capisco il senso.

Ci sono giochi mind-♥♥♥♥ molto più interessanti e appaganti di questo titolo.
Qui non ci sono discorsi di senso compiuti, e la trama pare una valanga di non-sense che ti viene sbattuta in faccia con la parvenza che dietro ci sia qualcosa di altamente filosofico, anche se in realtà così non è.

Il gameplay è strano, anche palloso per certi sensi, e la durata del titolo non aiuta, ma è meglio così... 10 ore di questa roba non le digerirei proprio.

Insomma: bello stile grafico, interessante.. peccato che sia l'unica cosa del titolo ad avere questa qualità.

NON. COMPRATELO.''

...''non ne capisco il senso'' -> gioco di ♥♥♥♥♥
Quante botte che mi darei se potessi tornare indietro nel tempo :D

author: {'steamid': '76561198063992304', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1459001200}
review:
"Thirty Flights of Loving" es valiente. Apenas dura media hora, constriñe la libertad del jugador dramáticamente y cuenta una historia críptica que necesitará varios visionados para ser entendida. Sus gráficos son toscos y no puede sacar músculo prácticamente en ningún aspecto.
El único aliciente que aporta, sin embargo, lo convierte en una obra obligada para todo el que quiera reflexionar sobre nuevas formas de contar en los videojuegos.

Hasta ahora, algo sustancial al cine, el montaje, sólo se había usado timidamente en el entretenimiento interactivo. "Alone in the Dark" abrió la puerta a varias cosas (entre ellas al género del survival horror), pero la principal fue su innovador uso de la cámara, en un incipiente montaje propiciado por la posición del avatar en la habitación.
"Thirty Flights of Loving" mantiene en todo momento la misma perspectiva visual y usa el montaje en un sentido plenamente cinematográfico, es decir: "corta" escenas y las (des)coloca en la línea temporal con una intención narrativa.
Su mérito es mostrarnos que es posible otro tipo de videojuego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041337724', 'num_games_owned': 1173, 'num_reviews': 150, 'playtime_forever': 40, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 40, 'last_played': 1467157750}
review: An unconventional small game that tells a small story very well. Great composition and sound design; a lot of work clearly went into it. Get it on sale if you need to, but do get it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998967954', 'num_games_owned': 1416, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1466971191}
review: A surprising lack of content and interactivity for a game rated so highly. It does have high points in that it's quick-cut action-style presentation is something I can't place in any other game. However, don't expect substantial meaty bits in between the quick cuts. Similarly, you'll have to contain your disbelief when the game ends in less than 15 minutes. Given just how very little game there is here and how much that contributes to an overall feeling of dissatisfaction when its over, I have to not recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198041880512', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 65, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 65, 'last_played': 1376273498}
review:
After playing the ~20 minute long game, you're given the option to replay with developer commentary. This mode takes you from scene to scene, but allows you to step back and look at how the game is constructed, on both a technical and storytelling level. You can noclip around each scene to look around, and interact with text bubbles that highlight notable design decisions. I enjoyed the game, but I even more enjoyed digging into how the game was made.

Blendo is a smart indie dev, getting to look into his design process was well worth $5 for me.

I find the game to be a great example of what games can be, and personally takes its place as one of my favorites, if for nothing more than the intresting ideas of this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010385289', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1583373577}
review:
I enjoyed the experience a lot. Yes it is short and yes a lot of people feel that it is not worth the price of admittance. Yes you could go watch a lets play if you feel like that is good enough. But it does include Gravity Bone in case you have not played that as well as an interesting commentary mode which should be noted.

In regards to price, this game was offered as a reward for the Idle Thumbs Kickstarter, I do not believe it was intended to be a standalone title. I see the price more as a punishment for not contributing to the kickstarter. Whether you want to buy it and take the ride is up to you.

As another review notes, I've spent more time thinking about this game than I did playing it. To me that's a good thing, it's an interesting stylistic experience that someone put some heart and soul into and to me that's inspiring and motivating.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998825270', 'num_games_owned': 522, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 34, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 34, 'last_played': 1458004223}
review:
I just finished Thirty Flights of Loving and I'm not sure what I just played. I do know that it's a roughly 10-15 minute experience telling a story about spies... carrying out a heist? ...I think? What I do know is that it was created by Brendon Chung, the one-man team behind Blendo Games who is also responsible for Flotilla, Atom Zombie Smasher and the upcoming Quadrilateral Cowboy. Thirty Flights of Loving (TFOL) was created as part of a Kickstarter campaign to support the Idle Thumbs podcast, of which I am a frequent listener. According to Chung, TFOL was an excercise in creating a game that tells a story without any dialogue. TFOL is certinaly a realization of that concept, but I don't think it's very successful in telling a clear and understandable story

Part of the problem here is that in order to get the whole picture of what's going on in TFOL, you had to have played some of Chung's previous games. TFOL opens by announcing that it's the sequel to a game called Gravity Bone, which is jarring to anyone (myself included) who wasn't aware of Gravity Bone and was expecting TFOL to be a standalone experience. I found TFOL to be a pretty hard and confusing game to parse through. Part of it is the lack of any dialogue, part of it is the smash cuts and non-linear presentation of the story, and part of it is the expectation that the audience has also played Gravity Bone. By doing a bit of research and also watching an excellent video by Errant Signal, I was able to find out that Gravity Bone is part of Chung's long running series of games called "Citizen Abel". Now I'm not sure if playing all of the other Citizen Abel games helps TFOL make more sense, but that's a lot to expect your audience to do espiecially considering some of the older Citizen Abel games are Quake II and Half Life II mods. And if having played those games doesn't contribute anything to the understanding of TFOL, why brand it as the sequel to Gravity Bone? I acknowledge that some my confusion with the story may be my own fault for not having played the other games, but this was one of several nits I had to pick with this game.

As I mentioned earlier, the story in TFOL is told non-linearly and without any dialogue at all. As you might guess, it makes the story a bit hard to follow. Even though I played through the game twice to try to piece it together, I still can't come up with a reading on this game that isn't jumbled nonsense. I'd love to hear someone else's interpretation of the story though, if someone can actually manage to follow it and come up with an understanding.

I'm all for smaller games made for a specific audience, so I feel bad picking on the little guy here. Nevertheless, I found TFOL to be a short and confusing experiment in weird and nonsensical storytelling. I've now written quite a few words about a game that has none.

For more game reviews, check out http://whatisjamesplaying.blogspot.com/

author: {'steamid': '76561197998220526', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 131, 'playtime_forever': 6, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 6, 'last_played': 1356681600}

author: {'steamid': '76561198040762042', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 103, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1469048319}
review: Very short experience but absolutely worth it, in my opinion. Thirty Flights puts most AAA games to shame with it's story telling and fantastic direction. I'd consider this as both a fully realized game and a test of the powerful ability video games have to convey emotion and art. Very rarely does a gamer get a chance like this... I'd recommend it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197987943631', 'num_games_owned': 1959, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1455984925}
review:
This game always crashed for me. One day, I decided to try to launch it again and it worked.

15 minutes later, I'm done.

I don't remember when and why I got this game, probably as part of a bundle? I probably wouldn't have if I knew what it was.

Honestly, I liked the way the game just throws you in without saying anything. A story unfolds as you move forward, skips through time. I'm still not sure I understood what was going on and I don't feel quite motivated enough to even think about it.

The concept was cool, it felt cool to go through and then it was over and none of my questions were answered. I have never played "Gravity Bones" but I don't feel like it would have helped.

If you get this game for free, play it, you'll be done in a few minutes. Otherwise, please don't buy it, there are so many cool games that can offer more than 15 minutes of entertainment for less than 5$.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081370956', 'num_games_owned': 95, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1487482529}
review: pretty good game

author: {'steamid': '76561197985241852', 'num_games_owned': 797, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 86, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 86, 'last_played': 1455597738}
review:
Brendon Chung became notable many years past for his odd-ball and unique contributions to Half-Life modding scene with projects such as 1986, The Bootleg Squaldron, Bug Stompers and The Puppy Years. 1986 being one of the first Half-Life mods I have installed and The Puppy Years being a personal favorite of mine.

So learning he was behind Thirty Flights of Loving made me ecstatic to buy and play.

30 minutes after installing I can safely say I finished it. I went back for more to play the commentary mode as well.

For the price of a nice sandwhich, a game this short would leave me rather infuriated, I mean I bought Rogue Warrior for 5 dollars after it got marked down from 69.99 and I beat that in an hour and a half when I realized performing execution moves on enemies restored my health and left me invulnerable during the action. That game left me angered, Thirty Flights of Loving was completed in a drastically shorter term and yet I left feeling delighted, mesmerized and intrigued.

And above all, absolutely confused.

The game flips expectations, delivers exposition without a single spoken word, is vibrant and all over the place in terms of design, story and themes. And I loved every second of this bizarre, wild ride.

It's short and given the current price, may be a little bit too expensive for some considering the amount of time it takes to beat it. However, those looking for a unique experience and wanting have a piece of fiction leave them asking "What!?" at every scene should look no Further with Thirty Flights of Loving. :)

author: {'steamid': '76561197980463699', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1421036730}
review: Interesting little game that plays with unusual visuals and storytelling techniques, but I'm not sure it works as a commercial release.  It feels like the gaming equivalent of a student film.  There's only about 20 minutes of gameplay so even at $5 it's a pretty poor value.

author: {'steamid': '76561198111697179', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 56, 'playtime_forever': 58, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 58, 'last_played': 1455468787}
review:
Hard Cut: The Game




Real talk though, this is a very short game that kinda serves more as an exercise in narrative more than anything else. In most games, story moments are broken up by gameplay and bosses, maybe just a level with some scenery. There is none of that here; You prep for a mission and then the games skips to the end before you even realize it. It does flashbacks, stylized shots, and vague narrative the same way Tarantino does movies, minus dialogue of course. If you're a connesuir of games or enjoy experimental storytelling, this is right up your alley. Otherwise, it's something to kill 10-12 minutes.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002599631', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 66, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 66, 'last_played': 1388095588}
review:
When Valve announced that you can permanently remove games from your Steam library, guess what game immediately came to mind?

I am SO glad I'm now an ex-owner of this 'game' that succeeds in being not only devoid of gameplay but also devoid of story. TFOL represents everything that's wrong with the lazy, meaningless, uncreative side of the indie developer scene. Trying to get away with selling pointless, zero-effort garbage by acting like it's "le art" so people can convince themselves they're intellectually superior for appreciating it is a mighty fine shithole of a market niche for the developer to carve out for himself.

Good riddance to bad rubbish.

author: {'steamid': '76561197960298430', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1365836400}
review:
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!  This isnt even a game...its about 10 minutes long, there is no challenge, barely a story, and its ugly to look at!  This game probably only cost $100 to make and was probably made in a day or less.  The only reason it got good reviews was because it was "original".  Its the same reason why modern art and paintings of smeared feces get good reviews....because some reviewers think it breaks the mold and brings something new.  Giving this a good review is dangerous for gaming....essentially anyone can spend half a day just throwing a bunch of polygons together, and as long as you can move around it will count as a game....dont support trash like this.  Literally the worst "game" I have ever played!

I would consider buying if it is 50 cents or less just so you can see how bad this game is....cant believe this crap got like an 85% on metacritic.  Just buy it to see how delusional some game reviewers are now and days!

-1/999999999

author: {'steamid': '76561197963075416', 'num_games_owned': 1148, 'num_reviews': 36, 'playtime_forever': 46, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 46, 'last_played': 1483856022}
review:
Wouldn't say this game is meant to be fun or a "game" in the traditional sense.  There's no open world, no dialog trees, and no dialog - plain and and simple..  It's short story told with narrative concision.

A lot of the TFoL's story is subtley told through the environment or "mise en scene".  Even the disjointed narrative can slowly be pieced back into a chronological order when you assess your surroundings.  There's a difference between a game that smash-cuts to the past with an accompanying "3 days prior..." intertitle and one that lets the viewer/interactee figure it out on their own.

The director's commentary is also a great addition for anyone interested in the developers design choices.  Same goes for the additional "prequel" content for anyone who wants flesh-out the TFoL universe.

If you're still on the fence, buy when in a bundle or sale and remember to utilize the steam refund policy.

author: {'steamid': '76561198079807830', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 20, 'playtime_forever': 71, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 71, 'last_played': 1453344793}
review: This comes with Gravity Bone and a developer's commentary mode for TFOL. I recommend this to anyone who's interested in video games as a storytelling medium. It's short but it's an experience you'll remember, even if you don't understand it (I'm not sure I did).

author: {'steamid': '76561198003301937', 'num_games_owned': 473, 'num_reviews': 49, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1452634210}
review: A 13-minute game that has crashed 13 times as I've tried to play it. It's a Walking Simulator that you head through to gather the stray elements of a silent Heist Plot. It wrings a lot of style out of its blocky art presentation, and the non-linear story of what happened during and after the liquor heist tingles the brain through jarringly rapid cuts. But it's so brief that even the $1.24 I paid for it on a sale feels too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996910394', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1403421300}
review: Pretty steep price for such a quick experience, but it's quite different and possibly worth a look for that alone. There's not much I can say without spoiling it, so I'll just say if you're not too put off by the price (seriously it's super short), and you want something on the more avant-garde side, check it out.

author: {'steamid': '76561197972307462', 'num_games_owned': 341, 'num_reviews': 19, 'playtime_forever': 96, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 96, 'last_played': 1354694400}

author: {'steamid': '76561198025378915', 'num_games_owned': 2188, 'num_reviews': 126, 'playtime_forever': 69, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 69, 'last_played': 1451690176}
review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198069022657', 'num_games_owned': 217, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1360569600}
review: My grandfather smoked his whole life. I was about 10 years old when my mother said to him "if you ever want to see your grandchildren graduate, you have to stop immediately." Tears welled up in his eyes when he realized what exactly was at stake. He gave it up immediately. Three years later he died of lung cancer. It was really sad and destroyed me. My mother said to me- "Don't ever smoke. Please don't put your family through what your grandfather put us through." I agreed. At 28 I have never touched a cigarette. I must say, I feel a very slight sense of regret for having never done it, because this game gave me cancer anyways

author: {'steamid': '76561198077449566', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 74, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'last_played': 1451178162}
review:
Be forewarned: even with the bonus Gravity Bone included, you're paying for barely half an hour of game. 

For hardcore Jazzpunk fans (and I emphasise "hardcore"), Thirty Flights of Loving may be worth getting on account of its similar playstyle and sense of humour. To me, it's a proof of concept, not a finished product which people should be charged money for.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970314107', 'num_games_owned': 2302, 'num_reviews': 917, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1451118455}
review:
My first attempt at playing Thirty Flights of Loving ended in a crash just a few minutes in. I gave it another go, powered through the included prequel Gravity Bone in about 20 minutes, and finished Thirty Flights proper in another 15. I went to bed and spent the next hour laying awake, thinking about it. If that sounds like a good time to you, by all means pick it up right now. If you're skeptical, read on.

TFoL is a very short narrative game about three people engaged in some less than legal dealings. The story is presented from first-person in a heavily stylized world that evokes the colorful spy thrillers of the late 60s and early 70s. There's little to do besides walk and trigger events, and the non-linear presentation of the tale makes it hard to follow exactly where you are and what is going on. It's an intense and confusing journey that's going to take more than a little digging on your part to make any sense of.

This is actually a pretty sharp contrast to Gravity Bone, which is a surreal vignette of the life of a spy. There's more interaction and actual gameplay there, with some exploration to do and simple inventory to use to accomplish your missions. A bizarre sense of humor that strays almost into Jazzpunk territory helps prop it up, and then it all ends quite suddenly, game and humor alike. I'm glad it's included with TFoL because it helps flesh out the strange world and its symbolism a bit, and finding the links between them is certainly interesting.

What you're getting is a heavily-stylized walking sim with loads of meaning behind the short, staccato scenes. The overall feel of the game is unsettled and almost dreamlike, inviting you to read into every part of the presentation. This isn't something like a Tale of Tales game where it's congratulating itself on how clever and meaningful it is, mind you. Every part of Thirty Flights of Loving simply is, it just exists to be experienced, and waits for you to divine the meaning for yourself. There is seriously not much game here, and it's hard to really suggest a purchase, but I consider my time with it well-spent. I might even revisit it to puzzle out more meaning, or just experience the 30-minute fever dream again.

And if nothing else, Thirty Flights of Loving presents one of the best explanations of the Bernoulli Principle I have ever seen. I don't think I've ever fully understood it until now, and I thank Blendo Games for that.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/audish#curation]curation page[/url]!

author: {'steamid': '76561198002764391', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 51, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 42, 'last_played': 1450975879}

review: A smart and clever treat.  When you see people claiming this is a five minute game you know they paid zero attention, did not bother to engage their brain (assuming they've got one), and simply ran through it. Don't rush, think as you move through the space, and don't assume the game's going to change your life just because it got some good reviews. It--like its predecessor, Gravity Bone, which is included--is a trifle in the best possible.

Not what I would call a game, but more like using a first-person interface to tell a short story.

author: {'steamid': '76561198048974498', 'num_games_owned': 2964, 'num_reviews': 812, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1450698396}
review:
I don't understand this game.  

   I don't understand why all the people have blocks for heads; I don't understand why they all go "murmer, murmer, murmer"  as if they're underwater when they talk; I don't understand whether you are actually just teleporting all over the place or if that's meant to represent a passage of time or even if it's just the fact of it being a "broken game"; I don't understand why it's so short and so pixel-y and still five dollars RRP in the Steam Store even though it's been out since 2012; I don't understand why it has the rather heavy rep that it has.  

   Maybe this is because I am, strictly speaking, more a member of the "Simpsons" generation, rather than the "Family Guy" generation; which is to say, post-modernism before it got out of control.  Maybe I is just a stoopid.  
 
   I don't understand it, which isn't to say that I didn't like it.  I just didn't 100% "get it".  And I think I liked "Gravity Bone", the bonus game included with it, more than the main game itself.  Which I still don't understand.  Do you understand what I'm saying?  I really, honestly DID NOT UNDERSTAND IT.

   But I still kinda liked it.

   Quentin Tarantino, you're a very talented man, but you have soooooo much to answer for.

   Recommended, but only to the curious, and probably only when on sale.

Verdict:  7.5/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992801270', 'num_games_owned': 3933, 'num_reviews': 188, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1366009200}
review: This is more an interactive movie than an actual game using the good ole' Quake 2 engine.  Interesting and worth 30 mins if you have the cash and want to check out something different.

author: {'steamid': '76561197970718011', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 49, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 49, 'last_played': 1450013027}
review:
I've loved Blendo games since I first encountered Gravity Bone, so I was thrilled to find out that it's included with this package.

The game itself is essentially a refinement of the storytelling seen in Gravity Bone - you never know all the facts, you never get all the answers, but the game never panders and the result is completely unique. It's not a game for everyone (least of all because it's so short), but if you're the right person this package is an hour of your life you'll never regret.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006740929', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 17, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 17, 'last_played': 1449803263}

author: {'steamid': '76561198077167910', 'num_games_owned': 572, 'num_reviews': 78, 'playtime_forever': 29, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 29, 'last_played': 1449039077}
review:
Ooh, a heist game that pays tribute to the films of Wong Kar-wai, tinted with the sensibilities of French New Wave, and is inspired by classic adventure games of yore! Sign me up!

Thirty Flights of Loving doesn't even last the amount of time indicated in its title, but the experience is as powerful as a dozen bottles of downed prohibited hooch to the gut.

Told through a series of jump cuts, you and your allies arrange a heist but -- as seen in the introduction -- it goes horribly wrong. Jump cuts send you back to an earlier time, then one less idyllic, then one utterly chaotic.

Twists and turns develop -- was that a ********* person ******* in my ***? It is! And what about the **** at the end? Despite the game being on rails, the narrative is not. 

Wait, rails? That's right. The game, more of an interactive short film, is essentially you holding W to move from jump cut to jump cut, and occasionally pressing E to interact with an object. Do this often, I implore you!

If you want to control a character that'll shootmens and look down at his 4K-textured hands and shout in desperate confusion, "What have I become?!" then this isn't the game for you. If you want to take a break from the usual games and follow along a neat little narrative, then strap yourself in for a ride.

After all, it's just a quick heist -- in and out. What have you got to lose?

author: {'steamid': '76561198142920541', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1610240322}

author: {'steamid': '76561197991432737', 'num_games_owned': 1179, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 15, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 15, 'last_played': 1445655537}
review:
I can honestly say I didn't know what to expect when I loaded up this game. I have a huge backlog and figured I'd get through it eventually and I started with the shortest playtime as per HLTB. 

The game crashed on me after starting and it still only took me 15 minutes to finish. The game is short, the art style isn't bad. For something that was supposedly superbly written, this is just so unfulfilling. It was not a masterpiece, not in any sense. The gameplay was very linear, and kind of jumpy all over the place. The story was easy to follow, at least what I got out of it.

I know this last part is going to be kind of stupid, but why did the game change my Windows brightness settings?

I do not recommend, as I don't see nor did I find any redeeming qualities within this title, and yes I read all the cards and looked at almost everything else on the walls. If you decide to get it anyway, wait for a sale, a big sale, like I did.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009381332', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 55, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1478738083}

If it's on sale for $1, maybe then you should consider picking it up.
